A teaspoon-full of seeds should be soaked in a glass of water over night, take that water along with seeds on empty stomach. After taking this water you should not take any food or medicine for the next 30 minutes. Continue this for 2 – 3 times per week.
Take half spoon of cinnamon power everyday in warm water or chewing naturally to get the desired effect. Boil two to four cinnamon sticks in one cup of water and allow it to steep for 20 minutes. Drink this solution daily to lower the blood glucose level.
A person can take 300mg per day or these seeds are ground and placed in capsules to reduce the blood sugar level. Grape seed are rich in vitamin E and flavonoids.
Cook food daily with edible olive oil effect on long run to reduce blood sugar level. It affects in reducing the cholesterol and triglycerides level in blood.
Bitter guard juice effects more when taken on empty stomach once in three days or take at least in the form of curry once in a week will decrease the sugar level in blood.
Consuming vitamin C up to 600mg daily or in the form of fruits, vegetables can help to control blood sugar.
Garlic has anti-diabetic and cholesterol reducing effect. Eat 3-4 raw garlic buds thus the Allicin chemical is to have hypoglycemic effects.
Mix one to two teaspoons of ground bay leaves, one teaspoon of turmeric and one teaspoon of aloe vera gel. Drink this solution daily before and after dinner. This combination helps in controlling blood sugar.
A neem tree has anti-bacterial, anti-fungal and anti-diabetic properties. Drink juice of neem leaves on an empty stomach reduce insulin requirements by up to 50%
Take two to three Indian gooseberries grind it and squeeze out the juice. Mix two tablespoon of the juice in one cup to water and drink it daily on an empty stomach.
Soak 10 to 15 mango leaves in a glass of water overnight. Filter the water and drink on an empty stomach or dry the leaves in the shade and grind them, eat one-half teaspoon of powder two times daily
Eat two to three tulsi leaves daily or one tablespoon of its juice on an empty stomach can lower blood sugar.
Soybean is filled with fiber, proteins, calcium and vitamin A will help to control blood sugar levels.
Eating guava can be helpful in maintain the blood sugar level as it consists of vitamin C and high fiber content.
Add vinegar to foods in your regular diet can be palatable and reduces sugar concentration in blood.
Healthy eating is not about strict dietary limitations, staying unrealistically thin, or depriving yourself of the foods you love. Vegetables are the foundation of a healthy diet. They are low in calories and nutrient dense, which means they are packed with vitamins, minerals, antioxidants and fiber. Eating more fresh vegetables is one of the simplest choices you can make to improve your overall health.
Vegetables with different colors provide different benefits. So you should eat rainbow of vegetables every day with every meal that keeps you with good health. Vegetables contain higher concentrations of minerals, vitamins and antioxidants.
Vegetables may be raw or cooked; fresh, frozen, canned, or dried/dehydrated; and may be whole, cut-up, or mashed. Based on their nutrient content, vegetables are organized into 5 subgroups: dark green vegetables, starchy vegetables, red and orange vegetables, beans and peas, and other vegetables.
Take vegetables that are bright and dark green lettuce. Mustard greens, Chinese cabbage, broccoli, spinach and kale are just a few of the options that all packed with calcium magnesium, potassium, iron, zinc and vitamins A, C, E and K.
Add healthy sweetness to your meals. The natural sweet vegetables are corn, yams, onions, corn, green bananas, green peas, water chestnuts and squash.
Red and orange vegetables are good sources of potassium, which is an essential nutrient for regulating your blood pressure. The red and orange vegetables are acorn squash, carrots, pumpkin, red peppers, sweet potatoes, tomatoes.
Beans are high in soluble fiber, folate, magnesium, iron and potassium. These heart healthy nutrients help to lower cholesterol, triglycerides, blood pressure and reduce risk of coronary artery disease, diabetes and osteoporosis.
There are some more other vegetables like avocado, cabbage, cauliflower, cucumber, eggplant, beets, mushrooms, okra, artichokes and asparagus.
The amount of vegetables you need to eat depends on your age, sex, and level of physical activity. Vegetable subgroup recommendations are given as amounts to eat weekly. It is not necessary to eat vegetables from each subgroup daily. However, over a week, try to consume the amounts listed from each subgroup as a way to reach your daily intake recommendation.
In general, 1 cup of raw or cooked vegetables or vegetable juice, or 2 cups of raw leafy greens can be considered as 1 cup from the Vegetable Group. The specific amounts that count as 1 cup of vegetables (in some cases equivalents for ½ cup are also shown) towards your recommended intake.
Eating vegetables provides health benefits with people who eat more vegetables and fruits as part of an overall healthy diet are likely to have a reduced risk of some chronic diseases. Vegetables provide nutrients vital for health and maintenance of your body.
Vegetables that are rich in fiber may reduce the risk of heart disease, obesity and type 2 diabetes.
Vegetables with high potassium may lower blood pressure and may reduce the risk of developing kidney stones and help to decrease bone loss.
Vegetables are important sources of many nutrients like potassium, dietary fiber, folate, vitamin A and vitamin C.
Organic verities tend to be smaller but have rich flavor, possess some good concentration of vitamins, minerals and loaded with numerous health benefiting anti-oxidants.
Look carefully for blemishes, spots, fungal mold and signs of insecticide spray. Buy whole vegetables instead of section of them (for example, pumpkin).
You need to do immediately after shopping, wash them, especially green leafy vegetables. Rinse in salt water for few minutes and gently swish in cool water until you are satisfied with cleanliness.
The scores from the other tests are used to determine what type of specialty you might be best suited for. These "composite" scores (also known as line scores, MOS scores, or aptitude area scores) are calculated by adding together combinations of the different sub test standard scores. These composite scores are then used to determine which different military jobs (aka Military Occupational Specialties or MOS) may be the best fit for you. Each branch of the military will have their own approach to these composite scores.
Composite Scores are sometimes referred to as “line scores”, “aptitude area scores”, or “MOS scores”. These scores are derived by adding different combinations of the sub test standard scores. Composite scores are used by the different branches of the U.S. Armed Services to determine which military jobs (or Military Occupational Specialities/MOS) may be the best fit for you. These composite scores are only one factor in determining which military job is right for you. The recruiter will also use job availability, physical and medical qualifications, and eligibility for security clearance as additional factors. Each branch of the service also defines their own composite scores and eligibility requirements. Some of these definitions and requirements are shown below:
I'm really not someone who likes to toot my own horn (at least not very loudly! tee hee) but I have to say it this time: Devin's custom made suit is a true piece of perfection. The cut, style, texture and material work harmoniously together.
We also have to give credit to Devin's athletic physique. He's a tall kid with a lean muscular body who can really pull off that slim fit trend that the Brits fancy so much.
1. THE COLOUR: Midnight Blue - Black to me always seems too formal (a black suit is better left for weddings, funerals and the times when the director of an MIB sequel needs a stand-in.) Navy screams "I'm wearing this suit to make myself look more approachable but in fact, I'm going to aggressively sell you something you may not even need." Devin's suit color is in between blue and black, which I think is supremely stylish and oozes sophistication. Chick's will dig it.
2. THE SHADOW STRIPES: A man with little fashion sense or is timid about stepping outside his comfort zone may find pin-stripes...daunting. Making a patterned suit work for you requires effort and let's face it, most guys aren't fashion savvy and really don't care how navy looks amazing with lavender. It's a girl's job to know how to look good, right? ;) So, that's why I recommend shadow stripes (alternating stripes of a dark and a light shade of the same colour). If you go this route, you don't need to worry about matching your stripes to your shirt, tie, shoes, glasses, rings, belt, eye colour, nose piercing, car, hair and so forth. You'd still be kicking up your style a notch because your suit has texture.
4. THE STYLE: I have a weakness for peaked lapels. It was a big trend that started in the 1920's and carried on until the 1930's. The style re-emerged during the 70's and has now been a hot trend for the last couple of years. Peaked lapels make you look smart. Together with a the two-button closure, they elongate your torso and make you look tall.
Devin clearly has a keen sense of style. He tops off his new suit with a pair of unique semi-glossy shoes and a black-placket front shirt.
This is Murray. He sports a head of lush long locks and an awesome beard which I'm guessing he will not shave off just because he's getting married. It's an extremely well-groomed beard though, I must say. He'd probably look like a baby if he were to get rid of it completely--which is maybe why he even has a beard in the first place. I bet he doesn't want to look like a baby getting married. Can you imagine? A baby getting married? That is too strange for anybody to imagine. I hope you don't try to imagine that. If you're reading this Murray, I hope you don't mind this self-discussion of your beard. I genuinely think your beard is awesome! I swear, really.
I'm a little nervous about writing again which explains the babbling. I've been absent from the world of blogging and I'm perfectly aware of that, so I apologize. Summer's been keeping me nice and busy. I'm really happy to be back though.
Murray was kind enough to let me photograph him wearing our waistcoat. From what I hear, his wedding attire as well as the bride's will be unconventional. I'm a fan of unconventional. I love traditional too but being unconventional amplifies the uniqueness and beauty of a couple's wedding.
Murray wanted a burgundy waistcoat that would match the colour of his bride's dress (Isn't that cool? Step aside, boring white!) and so we made this for him:
The "how-could-anybody-resist-giving-me-what-I-want" look. It's pretty darn powerful, I'll tell you that. I had to pull $50 out of my wallet for him to take this picture. Haha!
Murray couldn't contain his emotions when I asked him about his beard grooming regimen. Err, not that I have a beard or anything...
We received a lot of stares from passers-by (especially the ladies because they were jealous that I got to photograph Murray who possibly could pass for a GQ model). So, we came up with an idea that would help deflect those stares:
Murray pretended to ponder about stuff and not know me while I pretended to take pictures of Balsam's storefront and pretended not to know Murray.
This is Murray's backside. A totally unintentional shot. He spotted a man with a comparable beard and his eyes followed.
I have a multiset volatile table having 10k records and a table having 5 billion records. I have to create a multiset volatile table by inner joining these two tables. But, the query is failing due to spool space issue. Is there any way to tune this SQL, apart from increasing the spool space?
My first question would be if the inner join condition applies to the Primary Index (PI) of the larger table.
Otherwise the execution plan would probably try to redistribute those 5 billion records to Spool, preparing for join processing, and that would probably exhaust your user Spool quota.
So you can tune the SQL if the join condition is not currently applied to the PI of the larger table, check if this is feasible, depending on the volatile table design.
Skew or bad PI distribution could also be the problem, i.e. multiple records having same PI value in the result set would hash to same AMP and perhaps trigger the Spool space error (remeber the Spool quota is divided by the number of AMPs, and if just one AMP hits its own maximum the Spool space error occurs).
Normally to diagnose a problem like this and suggest SQL tuning one needs an EXPLAIN of the query and the DDL of the accessed tables.
To better understand the question we would need to know the SQL conditions relating the tables. Are these conditions selective or is it expected that the entire 5 billion rows would be included in the result? If the latter, then spool space for two copies of the 5 billion rows will be necessary - one for the join result and one for the final result. And of course those both would have all the columns of the result of the join.

AGV set out to change the game with its new full-carbon modular helmet. The Italian company boasts that the Sportmodular is the world’s first modular helmet constructed entirely out of carbon fiber which makes it a modular that is lighter than plenty of other helmets on the market, not just other modulars.
I’ve spent thousands of miles wearing the AGV Sportmodular through varying climates and on plenty of different motorcycles, and the helmet’s practicality and versatility has caused me to keep grabbing it on my way out the door.
The AGV Sportmodular is light. In fact, it’s the lightest helmet in my gear closet, weighing in at 3-pounds 2.6-ounces (1434 grams) for my medium. AGV uses three shell sizes for the Sportmodular with XS and S using the smallest, M and L using the next, and XL-XXXL fitting into the largest shell size. Within those three shells are four different size EPS liners, ensuring an optimum fit for sizes XS-XXXL.
The light nature of this carbon helmet is really the big story here. Historically, modular helmets tend to be some of the heaviest simply due to their more complex design. I haven’t weighed the AGV Numo or Miglia, the company’s previous modular models, but they both felt extremely heavy just grabbing one off the shelf, which makes the Sportmodular even more impressive and an important model for the brand.

Correspondence between James Connolly and John Carstairs Matheson, mainly on socialism and trade unionism in Ireland, Great Britain and America, 1902-1916.
Letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly asking Connolly to obtain books for him and writing about an election in Falkirk and various political figures in the United Kingdom, 1902 November 28.
Letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly about Matheson's teaching role, the Education Act of 1902 and various political events and figures in Scotland, 1903 September 11.
Letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly wishing him goodbye and good luck, 1903 September 15.
Letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly enquiring how Connolly is getting on in America, and suggesting that Connolly write the English verse of the translation of a German socialist song, 1903 December 4.
Letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly about the success of 'The Socialist' 1904 January 5.
Letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly requesting regular articles from him for 'The Socialist', 1904 March 28.
Letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly about an article by Connolly about Daniel De Leon to be published in 'The Socialist', 1904 May 16.
Letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly informing him that he replied to a letter from Daniel De Leon about Connolly, 1904 June 7.
Letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly expressing his frustation with some critics of 'The Socialist', 1904 June 7.
Letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly defending himself by reiterating what response he made to Daniel De Leon's letter enquiring about James Connolly, and stating his readiness to defend Connolly, 1904 August 3.
Letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly hoping that he and Lillie Connolly are settling in in America and relating Daniel De Leon's belief that Connolly would not be expelled from the Socialist Labour Party of America, 1904 October 7.
Letter from John Carstairs Matheson to an unidentified recipient confirming that he will be glad to publish any material by him, and enquiring after mutual acquaintances, 1905 February 9.
Letter from John Carstairs Matheson requesting a copy from the correspondent appointed by the Socialist Party of Ireland, 1905 March 13.
Letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly proposing that Connolly return to Scotland and act as printer of 'The Socialist', and recounting in detail some events and disagreements within the Socialist Labour Party, 1905 December 9.
Letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly about difficulties in the proposed move by Connolly to Scotland to act as printer of 'The Socialist', and predicting the affiliation of the Social Democratic Federation with the Labour Representation Committee, 1906 March 12.
Letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly stating that he still hopes to be able to invite Connolly to return work in Scotland, and telling him of political events and figures in the United Kingdom, 1906 May 27.
Letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly about local views of the relationship between the American and British Socialist Labour Parties, the new compositor for 'The Socialist' and various political events and figures, 1906 June 20.
Letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly about Connolly's role in the United States, the success of the Socialist Labour Party and its industrial union propaganda, and Matheson's intention to cease as editor of 'The Socialist', 1907 March 2.
Letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly seeking practical information on the administration of the Industrial Workers of the World and referring to Connolly's writings about Daniel De Leon, 1907 April 21.
Postcard from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly about political events and figures and referring to charges made against Daniel De Leon, 1907 October 14.
Letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly about their newspapers, party salaries and Connolly's differences with Daniel De Leon, 1907 November 17.
Letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly about Connolly's songbook, articles by Matheson, and Daniel De Leon and William D. Haywood, 1907 November 19.
Letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly expressing frustration about the Independent Labour Party in Ireland and seeking Connolly's advice on the issue, 1907 November 25.
Letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly offering advice in relation to Connolly's account of Daniel De Leon, and Connolly's role in the foundation of the Socialist Labour Party, 1907 December 22.
Letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly about the troubles facing the Socialist Labour Parties in the United States and the United Kingdom, 1908 February 16.
Letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly confirming he had sent to Connolly copies of a 1903 issue of 'The Socialist' in praise of Connolly, and refers to Daniel De Leon and other political figures and events in Britain, 1908 March 16.
Letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly about Connolly's differences with Daniel De Leon, and the relationship between the Socialist Labour Party and the Advocates of Industrial Unionism, 1908 April 2.
Letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly about the level of support for Connolly in Scotland as regards to his differences with Daniel De Leon, 1908 April 8.
Circular letter from Thomas Drummond, editor of 'Industrial Bulletin', to the members of the Advocates of Industrial Unionism regarding the holding back of the circulation of Issue 2, 1908 April 17.
Letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly referring to Connolly's "proposed emigration", the reaction to Connolly's attitude to Sinn Féin, and other political matters, 1908 April 27.
Letter by Thomas Drummond, editor of 'Industrial Bulletin', written on verso of a 'Industrial Bulletin' article, to "M" regarding the Socialist Labour Party and the Sheffield Conference, [1908].
Letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly enclosing a copy of a letter Matheson received from G. Geis, and asking about the New York Industrial District Council, 1908 June 19.
Letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly in which he seeks to understand Connolly's side of the situation where Daniel De Leon "wanted to get rid of you - and he has", 1908 September 8.
Letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly about Daniel De Leon's charges, disagreement within the Socialist Labour Party, unemployment and unrest in Scotland, 1908 October 12.
Letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly in which he states that he does not "want to mix myself up in any of these American rows" and writes of feeling "very depressed and dispirited" over political difficulties, 1908 November 17.
Letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly about charges made by Daniel De Leon against James Connolly and Frank Bohn and related meeting minutes, 1908 December 5.
Letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly regarding a pamphlet about anarchism, Matheson's resignation as editor of 'The Socialist', and polical events in Scotland and the United States, 1909 January 31.
Letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly about unions and politics in the United Kingdom, the United States and France, 1909 March 23.
Letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly about local political affairs, and an article in 'Forward' possibly suggesting Matheson, falsely, as the author of an anonymous letter and seeking Connolly's help and advice in the matter, 1910 October 2.
Letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly about arranging to meet, Connolly's return from the United States and Matheson's relationship with the Independent Labour Party, 1910 October 7.
Letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly about Matheson's forthcoming review of a book by Connolly to appear in 'The Socialist', 1910 December 11.
Letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly about the reviews of Connolly's book, 1911 January 6.
Letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly about a case that Connollly mentioned concerning "Farrell" and his likely attempt to seek publication in 'The Socialist', 1911 January 10.
Letter from Jane Carstairs Matheson on behalf of her husband John Carstairs Matheson to William O'Brien in response to O'Brien's letter regarding James Connolly's letters John Carstairs Matheson, 1916 November 2.
Letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly about a disagreement between Connolly and George S. Yates relating to 'The Socialist', 1903 February 11.
Letter from James Connolly to John Carstairs Matheson regarding the acknowledgment of political donations, 1902 March 13.
Letter from James Connolly to John Carstairs Matheson about intrigues within the Social Democratic Federation, 1902 March 14.
Letter from James Connolly to John Carstairs Matheson about Connolly's forthcoming visit to Scotland and Harry Quelch, 1902 March 24.
Letter from James Connolly to John Carstairs Matheson about a manifesto by Matheson and political matters in Scotland, 1902 May 9.
Letter from James Connolly to John Carstairs Matheson about publication problems and the political situation in Manchester and Lancashire, 1902 July 14.
Letter from James Connolly to John Carstairs Matheson outlining the limit of the corrections that can be made to articles prior to printing in 'The Socialist', and telling of his plans for a trip to the United States, 1902 August 22.
Letter from James Connolly to "Dear comrade" [John Carstairs Matheson] regarding financial and other matters related to printing [of 'The Socialist'?], 1902 August 28.
Letter from James Connolly to John Carstairs Matheson decling to give suggestions in advance of a conference, and writing about a failed move in Rhode Island against Dan [de Leon], [1903] January 21.
Letter from James Connolly to John Carstairs Matheson giving his opinion of Con Lehane, [1903 Feb?].
Letter from James Connolly to John Carstairs Matheson about a delay in printing due to "the turmoil of election printing" and about Matheson's possible expulsion, [1903 Feb?].
Letter from James Connolly to John Carstairs Matheson about a party dispute in Ireland, the impact of the Socialist Labour Party's sudden withdrawal from Dublin, of the printing of 'The Socialist', and about Connolly's need to find a home for his family and employment, 1903 March 9.
Letter from James Connolly to "Dear Sir" [John Carstairs Matheson] asserting that he is not to be confused with a writer of verse in the United Kingdom, about being poverty stricken and employment, and about the possible expulsion of [George S.] Yates, 1903 March 24.
Letter from James Connolly to John Carstairs Matheson warning him of talk that Social Democratic Federation's funds had been stolen to set up 'The Socialist', about Connolly's intention to move to the United States in the autumn, and seeking to encourage Matheson in his local political struggles, 1903 April 8.
Letter from James Connolly to John Carstairs Matheson about faked reports relating to the Social Democratic Federation and about party branches in Scotland including a new one in Kirkcaldy, 1903 June 24.
Letter from James Connolly to John Carstairs Matheson asking him to print an article that Connolly has written to answer [Daniel] De Leon's charge against Connolly, 1904 May 6.
Letter from James Connolly to John Carstairs Matheson telling how he is to be tried by the party in Troy and possibly expelled, and about how he intends to fight [Daniel] De Leon, 1904 May 26.
Letter from James Connolly to John Carstairs Matheson enclosing a copy of Connolly's defence [for his trial by the Troy section of the party], about articles on the subject and about Connolly having received word from Dublin that his wife was dangerously ill, 1904 June 22.
Letter from James Connolly to John Carstairs Matheson in praise of the paper ['The Socialist'], about Dan [De Leon]'s response at a convention to correspondence from Connolly, advising that Mrs Connolly expects to travel to the United States in August, and thanking Matheson for his support, 1904 July 22.
Letter from James Connolly to John Carstairs Matheson about his difficulties in the printing trade and current employment as a machinist, the relationship between various parties in the United States, the relationship with similar parties in Europe and Daniel De Leon, 1905 November 19.
Letter from James Connolly to John Carstairs Matheson in which he states that he is not against Matheson's suggestion that Connolly return to Scotland but must consider his family, and giving information about setting up a printing press, [1905 December 29].
Letter from James Connolly to John Carstairs Matheson thanking him for newspapers, praising [The Soclialist], and about George Yates, 1906 April 17.
Letter from James Connolly to John Carstairs Matheson expressing frustation with the socialist movement and its publications in the United States, observing that "everything must filter through Dan" and speculating about possible effects on the movement , 1906 June 10.
Letter from James Connolly to John Carstairs Matheson recounting details of recent party elections and votes, and about Daniel De Leon and his 'Flashlights', 1906 December 13.
Letter from James Connolly to John Carstairs Matheson about the third Convention of the Industrial Workers of the World, relations between Daniel De Leon, [Eugene Victor] Debs and [William Ernst] Trautmann, plans for a new Irish Socialist Federation publication, and Connolly's recent role as New York organiser for Industrial Workers of the World, 1907 September 27.
Letter from James Connolly to John Carstairs Matheson about "La belle Flynn" [Elizabeth Gurley Flynn], Daniel De Leon and the idea that the "Socialist world must be De Leonites or anti-De Leonites", and Connolly's life in America, with list of debts owed to 'Daily People' employees, 1907 October 28.
Letter from James Connolly to John Carstairs Matheson advising Matheson to fight rather than resign as editor [of 'The Socialist'], about members of and subscribers to American socialist organisations and publications, and Daniel De Leon, [Frank] Bohn and [Eugene Victor] Debs, [1907?].
Letter from James Connolly to John Carstairs Matheson about 'The Harp', "Woodhouse", salaries in the American socialist movement, and outlining how Connolly plans to defend himself against party charges, 1907 December 10.
Letter from James Connolly to John Carstairs Matheson expressing frustration about the Socialist movement in the United States, and about the "Unity" resolution, a meeting about New York longshoremen joining the Industrial Workers of the World and the role of that organisation, 1908 January 30.
Letter from James Connolly to John Carstairs Matheson about Daniel De Leon being "defeated" in New York City, the class issue, Connolly's defence of himself at a meeting, his opinion of the socialist movement in the United Kingdom, and a letter to the United States from Scotland vouching for Connolly's character, 1908 March 1.
Letter from James Connolly to John Carstairs Matheson about Industrial Workers of the World's politicial versus economic actions and candidates, and seeking Matheson's opinion about Connolly's possible return to Dublin, 1908 April 8.
Letter from James Connolly to John Carstairs Matheson about the issue of political versus economic action for the working class in the United States compared to the United Kingdom, and the possible effect in the latter of what Connolly sees as the likely and imminent fall of Daniel De Leon, [1908?] April.
Letter from James Connolly to John Carstairs Matheson expressing disappointment that a letter of character for him from Scotland has not yet been received in the United States, and about economic action, running election candidates and how the Socialist Labour Party of America "has failed and is discredited", 1908 May 7.
Postcard from James Connolly to John Carstairs Matheson in praise of a letter by Matheson, confirming that Connolly has asked for a party trial and advising that he is currently unwell, 1908 June 6.
Postcard from James Connolly to John Carstairs Matheson expressing bitter disappointment at a delay, by then of two months, in receiving from Scotland a letter of character for him, 1908 June 21.
Letter from James Connolly to John Carstairs Matheson about how he feels socialist parties should work and pointing to differences between American and British parties, and about the Industrial Workers of the World fourth convention, 1908 September 27.
Letter from James Connolly to John Carstairs Matheson about election votes for Daniel De Leon, [Morris] Hillquit and [Eugene Victor] Debs and how the socialist movement in the United Kingdom might respond to events in the United States, 1908 November 8.
Letter from James Connolly to John Carstairs Matheson taking issue with a reprint in 'The Socialist' of Daniel De Leon's pamphlet 'Anarchism and Socialism', 1908 December 20.
Letter from James Connolly to John Carstairs Matheson telling of Connolly's disappointment at his lack of success in obtaining a job in Ireland, and about the lesson he has learned in relation to the roles of socialism and the labour movement, 1909 June 10.
Letter from James Connolly to John Carstairs Matheson informing him that 'The Harp' has been suspended following libel cases and mismanagement since its transfer to Dublin, and about the actions of an agent, Mr. O'Farrell, selling 'The Socialist' in Dublin, 1911 January 9.
Letter from James Connolly to John Carstairs Matheson expressing disappointment about 'The Harp' and about an agent, Mr. Farrell, selling 'The Socialist' in Dublin , 1911 January 11.
Letter from James Connolly to John Carstairs Matheson about how each of them views the progress of the socialist movement, comparing the British and Irish situations, and recommending books on Irish history, 1911 April 18.
Letter from James Connolly to John Carstairs Matheson in which he refers to "this women's business" and "their hearty rebellion", to the [1911?] Insurance Act, and to the issues of compulsory contributions and compulsory arbitration, 1913 June 6.
Letter from James Connolly to John Carstairs Matheson thanking him for the letter he wrote while Connolly was in prison, of which he later got a copy since he did not receive the original, 1913 October 13.

Copy of a letter from James Connolly to "Dear Sir" [John Carstairs Matheson] asserting that he is not to be confused with a writer of verse in the United Kingdom, about being poverty stricken and employment, and about the possible expulsion of [George S.] Yates, 1903 March 24.
Copy of a letter from James Connolly to John Carstairs Matheson warning him of talk that Social Democratic Federation's funds had been stolen to set up 'The Socialist', about Connolly's intention to move to the United States in the autumn, and seeking to encourage Matheson in his local political struggles, 1903 April 8.
Copy of a letter from James Connolly to John Carstairs Matheson about faked reports relating to the Social Democratic Federation and about party branches in Scotland including a new one in Kirkcaldy, 1903 June 24.
Copy of a letter from James Connolly to John Carstairs Matheson asking him to print an article that Connolly has written to answer [Daniel] De Leon's charge against Connolly, 1904 May 6.
Copy of a letter from James Connolly to John Carstairs Matheson telling how he is to be tried by the party in Troy and possibly expelled, and about how he intends to fight [Daniel] De Leon, 1904 May 26.
Copy of a letter from James Connolly to John Carstairs Matheson enclosing a copy of Connolly's defence [for his trial by the Troy section of the party], about articles on the subject and about Connolly having received word from Dublin that his wife was dangerously ill, 1904 June 22.
Copy of a letter from James Connolly to John Carstairs Matheson in praise of the paper ['The Socialist'], about Dan [De Leon]'s response at a convention to correspondence from Connolly, advising that Mrs Connolly expects to travel to the United States in August, and thanking Matheson for his support, 1904 July 22.
Copy of a letter from James Connolly to John Carstairs Matheson about his difficulties in the printing trade and current employment as a machinist, the relationship between various parties in the United States, the relationship with similar parties in Europe and Daniel De Leon, 1905 November 19.
Copy of a letter from James Connolly to John Carstairs Matheson in which he states that he is not against Matheson's suggestion that Connolly return to Scotland but must consider his family, and giving information about setting up a printing press, [1905 December 29].
Copy of a letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly asking Connolly to obtain books for him and writing about an election in Falkirk and various political figures in the United Kingdom, 1902 November 28.
Copy of a letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly about a disagreement between Connolly and [George S.] Yates relating to 'The Socialist', 1903 February 11.
Copy of a letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly about Matheson's teaching role, the Education Act of 1902 and various political events and figures in Scotland, 1903 September 11.
Copy of a letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly wishing him goodbye and good luck, 1903 September 15.
Copy of a letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly enquiring how Connolly is getting on in America, and and suggesting that Connolly write the English verse of the translation of a German socialist song, 1903 December 4.
Copy of letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly confirming that he has sent money to Mrs Connolly and offering any assistance, about the success of "the paper" ['The Socialist'?] and about other political events and people, 1904 January 5.
Copy of letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly expressing relief at hearing from Connolly and requesting regular articles from him for the soon-to-be enlarged paper ['The Socialist'], 1904 March 28.
Copy of letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly about an article by Connolly about Dan [de Leon] to be published [in 'The Socialist'] and the personal and political issues raised by it, 1904 May 16.
Copy of letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly informing him that he replied to a letter from Dan [de Leon] about Connolly, 1904 June 7.
Copy of letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly expressing support for Connolly and expressing frustation with some critics [of 'The Socialist'], 1904 June 7.
Copy of letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly defending himself by reiterating what response he made to Dan [de Leon]'s letter enquiring about James Connolly, and stating his readiness to defend Connolly, 1904 August 3.
Copy of letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly hoping that he and Lillie Connolly are settling in in America and relating Dan [de Leon]'s belief that Connolly would not be expelled from the Socialist Labour Party of America, 1904 October 7.
Copy of letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly thanking Connolly for some papers, enquiring about Connolly's employment and about various figures and local events in the United Kingdom, 1904 December 23.
Copy of letter from John Carstairs Matheson to "Dear comrade" [James Connolly] confirming that he will be glad to publish any material by him, and enquiring after mutual acquaintances, 1905 February 9.
Copy of letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly proposing that Connolly return to Scotland and act as printer of "our paper" ['The Socialist'], recounting in detail some events and disagreements within the Socialist Labour Party, and confirming that he is again editor of 'The Socialist', 1905 December 9.
Copy of letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly about difficulties in the proposed move by Connolly to Scotland to act as printer [of 'The Socialist'], and predicting the affiliation of the Social Democratic Federation with the Labour Representation Committee, 1906 March 12.
Copy of letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly stating that he still hopes to be able to invite Connolly to return work in Scotland, and telling him of political events and figures in the United Kingdom, 1906 May 27.
Parital copy of letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly about local views of the relationship between the American and British Socialist Labour Parties, the new compositor [for 'The Socialist'] and about various political events and figures, 1906 June 20.
Copy of letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly about Connolly's role in the United States, the success of the Socialist Labour Party and its industrial union propaganda, and Matheson's intention to cease as editor of ['The Socialist'], 1907 March 2.
Copy of letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly seeking practical information on the administration of the Industrial Workers of the World and referring to Connolly's writings about Dan [De Leon], 1907 April 21.
Text of a postcard from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly about political events and figures and referring to charges made against Daniel [De Leon], 1907 October 14.
Copy of letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly about their newspapers, party salaries and Connolly's differences with Dan [De Leon], 1907 November 17.
Copy of letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly about Connolly's songbook, articles by Matheson, and Daniel [De Leon] and [William D.] Haywood, 1907 November 19.
Copy of letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly expressing frustration about the ILP in Ireland and seeking Connolly's advice on the issue, 1907 November 25.
Copy of letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly offering advice in relation to Connolly's account of Dan [De Leon], and about Connolly's role in the foundation of the SLP, [George S.] Yates' claim to be its "father" and Matheson's opinion of 'The Daily People', 1907 December 22.
Copy of letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly about the possible provision of a letter to Connolly about his "stainless and meritorious record in the Socialist Labout Party", party troubles in the United States and the United Kingdom, 1908 February 16.
Copy of letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly confirming he had sent to Connolly copies of a 1903 issue of 'The Socialist' in praise of Connolly, and referring to Dan [De Leon] and political figures and events in Britain, 1908 March 16.
Copy of letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly about Connolly's differences with [Daniel] De Leon, the relationship between the Socialist Labour Party and the Advocates of Industrial Unionism, and enclosing letters from other correspondents, 1908 April 2.
Copy of letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly advising that "the letter you require" should be given soon and writing about the level of support for Connolly in Scotland as regards to his differences with Daniel De Leon, 1908 April 8.
Copy of letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly referring to Connolly's "proposed emigration", the reaction to Connolly's attitude to Sinn Féin, and other political matters, 1908 April 27.
Copy of letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly confirming he has asked for a copy of a letter to be sent to Connolly, enclosing a copy of a letter Matheson received from G. Geis, and asking about the New York Industrial District Council, 1908 June 19.
Copy of letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly in which he seeks to understand Connolly's side of the situation where [Daniel De Leon] "wanted to get rid of you - and he has", 1908 September 8.
Copy of letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly about "De Leon's charges", disagreement within the Socialist Labour Party, unemployment and unrest in Scotland, 1908 October 12.
Copy of letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly in which he states that he does not "want to mix myself up in any of these American rows" and writes of feeling "very depressed and dispirited" over political difficulties, 1908 November 17.
Copy of letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly about charges made by Daniel De Leon against James Connolly and [Frank] Bohn and related meeting minutes, and giving his opinion of that party, 1908 December 5.
Copy of letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly regarding a pamphlet about anarchism, Matheson's resignation as editor [of 'The Socialist'], and polical events in Scotland and the United States, 1909 January 31.
Copy of letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly about unions and politics in the United Kingdom, the United States and France, 1909 March 23.
Partial copy of a letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly about local political affairs, and about an article in 'Forward' possibly suggesting Matheson, falsely, as the author of an anonymous letter and seeking Connolly's help and advice in the matter, 1910 October 2.
Copy of letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly about arranging to meet, Connolly's return from the United States and Matheson's relationship with the ILP [Independent Labour Party?], 1910 October 7.
Copy of letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly about Matheson's forthcoming review of a book by Connolly to appear in 'The Socialist' and Matheson's views on socialists of one country intervening in the matters of another country, 1910 December 11.
Copy of letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly about reaction to Connolly's book, thanking Connolly for sending some election literature, and subscribing to 'The Harp', 1911 January 6.
Copy of letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly about a case that Connollly mentioned concerning "Farrell" and his likely attempt to seek publication [in 'The Socialist'], 1911 January 10.
Copy of a letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly about the Scottish reaction to the "strike" [1913 lockout?] and an article about it, and the 'Daily Herald' and its stance on "snydicalism", 1913 October 18.
Copy of a letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly about an article in 'The Socialist' on "the Dublin strike", an "attack" on Connolly in the 'Weekly People' and an article in the 'Liberator' on the Socialist movement in the United States, with an enclosed letter from Jane Matheson asking if she may quote Connolly in support of women in her reply to an article in the 'Socialist' on suffragettes, 1913 November 15.
Copy of a letter from Jane C. Matheson on behalf of her husband John Carstairs Matheson to a Mr O'Brien in response to O'Brien's letter relating to letters of James Connolly's, 1916 November 2.

Letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien asking that he make appropriate enquiries in relation to gas money and an acquaintance's stories about monies found, and thanking O'Brien for his help in embarassing circumstances related to a suit of clothes, 1902 June 7.
Letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien in which he states his willingness to resign from the [Irish Socialist Republican] Party if O'Brien will continue in it, 1903 March 21.

Letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien about [Daniel] De Leon's "attack on me", the setting up of the [Irish Socialist Federation] and the upcoming International Socialist Congress, 1907 April 15.
Letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien enclosing money for subscriptions and requesting at least 500 copies of a pamphlet, 1907 May 20.
Letter from James Connolly to [J.W. O'Beirne,] manager of the 'Irish Nation', providing content for the January [1908?] issue of 'The Harp' and making arrangements for its printing since he has "resolved to give up the contract", [1909] December 1.
Partial letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien expressing a desire to move back to Ireland, hoping that O'Brien can "get that job for me" but recognising the financial costs of moving with his family, 1909 May 24.
Letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien and others, thanking them for their efforts to get Connolly a position in Ireland, expressing his disappointment at that failure, and outlining his ideas for trade unionism in Ireland, 1909 July 5.
Letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien about his position as national organiser for the Socialist Party of America, the possibility of his return to Ireland, his "plan of action for Ireland", and his hopes to have 'Labour in Irish history' published in London, 1909 September 12.
Letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien proposing how 'The Harp' might be printed in Dublin, which would enable him to move back to Dublin to take care of it, 1909 October 3.
Postcard from James Connolly to William O'Brien promising a copy of a manuscript and enquiring whether O'Brien has abandoned "the other matter" [of enabling Connolly to return to Ireland], 1909 October 20.
Letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien acknowledging receipt of quotations for printing 'The Harp', outlining his plans for the paper, and confirming that he will send a copy of a book ['Labour in Irish history'] to [Francis] Sheehy Skeffington, 1909 November 2.
Letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien informing him that 'The Harp' is the "property of comrade Donnelly" who does not wish to be involved once it transfers to Ireland, and communicating other information about the paper, 1909 November 03.
Letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien seeking acknowledgment of the receipt of books sent by Connolly to the Socialist Party of Ireland, and requesting weekly copies of the 'Freemason' and the 'Independent', 1909 November 19.
Letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien about copy for 'The Harp', Connolly's possible return to Ireland "for the cause" and elaborating on his views for trade unions in Ireland, 1909 December 6.
Letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien attempting to clarify Connolly's intentions in transferring the printing and publishing of 'The Harp' to Dublin regardless of whether Connolly himself returns to Ireland, 1909 December 18.
Letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien re-iterating his desire to have 'The Harp' published in Ireland and informing O'Brien about an offer he has made to the 'Irish Nation' if they will take care of it, and explaining his reasons for not making a trip to Ireland, 1909 December 20.
Letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien stating that he is considering an "experimental trip" to Ireland prompted by the offer of a job elsewhere, and expressing his satisfaction on hearing that [James] Larkin will manage 'The Harp', 1910 March 7.
Letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien confirming that he will be in Dublin in the last week of July, about where he will travel within Ireland and Britain and how his trip will be publicised, and expressing a preference that [James] Larkin be involved in organising Connolly's tour, [1910] May 3.
Letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien enclosing subscription money for 'The Harp' and requesting a statement of account before sending more, and about his proposed trip to Ireland in July, 1910 May 14.
Letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien asking if 'The Harp' is "alive or dead" as the May issue has not been received and asking about subscription monies he sent to Dublin that have not been acknowledged, 1910 May 29.
Letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien explaining why he wrote previously to O'Brien instead of to [James] Larkin, about the Belfast portion of Connolly's trip to Ireland and Connolly's attitude to the Irish Independent Labour Party, and about his reply to Father Kane, 1910 June 6.
Letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien about James Larkin's imprisonment, matters related to Connolly's upcoming lecture tour in Ireland and Britain, and the continued non-arrival of 'The Harp', 1910 June 24.
Postcard from James Connolly to William O'Brien reassuring O'Brien that he does not hold him responsible for circumstances, 1910 July 14.
Telegram from James Connolly to William O'Brien to advise that his ship has landed [from the United States] and he will be in Dublin at 1[pm?] on Tuesday, 1910 July 26.
Letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien asking why he has not been paid monies due to him, and asking about the prices of buttons and for an account with future materials, [1910 August].
Letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien expressing hope that Connolly's tour has been seen as a success, promoting support for new branches, advising that Belfast people want a conference in Dublin, and declining an offer of employment as an organiser in Ireland, 1910 September 5.
Letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien informing him that Belfast comrades plan to visit Dublin on September [18?] and urging Dublin to receive them well for the first such Socialist gathering in Ireland, 1910 September 12.
Letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien about a conference in Dublin for comrades visiting from Belfast, and elaborating on his reasons for declining an offer of employment as an organiser in Ireland, 1910 September 16.
Letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien advising that he is making plans to return to America and asking if there is enough business in Ireland to justify him travelling from Queenstown [Cobh], 1910 September 20.
Letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien requesting copies of 'Labour', asking about the conference [in Dublin for Belfast comrades] and asking O'Brien to let him know about James Larkin's intentions after his release from prison, 1910 September 27.
Letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien requesting 50 books, title unspecified, to be sent to him in Scotland, 1910 September 28.
Letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien outlining his ideas as to how Connolly might work in Ireland and be paid, enclosing a statement to members, and giving his opinion about his possible employment with the Irish Transport Workers' Union for O'Brien to communicate to James Larkin, 1910 October 2.
Letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien requesting pamphlets and enquiring about stock and reprinting of same, 1910 October 5.
Letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien on learning of the failure of his proposal to consider the establishment of an organiser's fund, his unwillingness to go on the payroll [of the Irish Transport and General Workers' Union], and his belief that Irish socialists must fight elections, 1910 October 11.
Postcard from James Connolly to William O'Brien asking that O'Brien not pursue the idea of a trip by Connolly to Dublin and Cork as Connolly does not wish to risk a delay to his return to America, 1910 October 12.
Postcard from James Connolly to William O'Brien saying "Your letter received. All right, go ahead", 1910 October 24.
Postcard from James Connolly to William O'Brien about an appeal in 'Forward' that money be sent to O'Brien, 1910 October 31.
Postcard from James Connolly to William O'Brien saying "will be in Dublin on Sunday", 1910 November 5.
Postcard from James Connolly to the secretary of the Socialist Party of Ireland about a complaint that Miss [Helena] Moloney has not received her membership card although elected on January 23, 1911 February 12.
Letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien about a resolution regarding the payment of members [of Parliament], the failure of Dublin to reply to letters from Belfast branch and the success of that branch since its reorganisation, 1911 February 14.
Letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien urging O'Brien to "lift the party out of the rut" and expressing his belief that his own time would be better spent in Ireland than in the United Kingdom, 1911 May 22.
Letter from James Connolly [to William O'Brien?] advising against believing [James] Larkin in relation to a couple of matters, and about roles and abilities within the party, 1911 May 24.
Postcard from James Connolly to William O'Brien about an article by [William?] Walker in 'Forward' and requesting material to be sent to Connolly immediately, 1911 May 31.
Postcard from James Connolly to William O'Brien requesting that an account of the Labour Party congress be sent to 'Forward' and to Connolly, 1911 June 12.
Postcard from James Connolly to William O'Brien stating that he will be "at the rooms on Wednesday evening" and would like to talk with him, 1911 August 15.
Telegram from James Connolly to William O'Brien requesting a speaker and advising of Connolly's arrival by train that night, 1911 August 26.
Letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien giving news of progress in Belfast and asking for news fom Dublin, 1911 December 7.
Telegram from James Connolly to William O'Brien referring to the political future of Labour in Ireland, 1912 January 26.
Letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien about possible articles and pamphlets, and the opportunity to create a "great Labour movement", 1912 June 29.
Letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien about a possible lecture by Connolly, 1912 September 11.
Letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien expressing dissatisfaction with James Larkin, "the general inactivity" and "playing to one man", and offering advice as to how to handle the situation, 1912 September 13.
Letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien apologising for not writing sooner to O'Brien and Fred Ryan as his time has been taken up with election and trade union matters, 1913 January 3.
Telegram from James Connolly to William O'Brien saying "The Labour movement in Ulster", 1913 January 22.
Postcard from James Connolly to William O'Brien requesting details of Labour candidates in Dublin and elsewhere in Ireland for use in an article in 'Forward', 1913 January 30
Postcard from James Connolly to William O'Brien confirming that he has booked rooms in Cork and requesting details of excursion trains from Dublin, 1913 May 5.
Telegram from James Connolly to William O'Brien saying "Book Conley Lawlor mill workers demonstration here Monday night", 1913 May 31.
Letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien confirming a meeting for June 9, and about strikes in Northern Ireland and a rival union The Belfast Transport Workers Union, with note of expenses, f 1913 June 6.
Letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien about a joint committee and the issue of Home rule, and explaining in confidence why he feels that he cannot tolerate James Larkin as his boss for much longer, 1913 July 29.
Telegram from James Connolly to William O'Brien advising that Connolly will be in Dublin on Monday, 1913 October 26.
Letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien outlining Connolly's advice to James Larkin regarding the resumption of work and the issue of working with non-union labour, [1913 November/December].
Letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien offering advice as to the circumstances in which to use a solicitor and when to defend oneself in cases, and describing Belfast branch as "almost bankrupt and broken up", 1914 May 4.
Letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien in which he expresses hope that a Congress will have a positive effect [on James Larkin] and that he will remain in Dublin, about a deputation to London, and a possible fund to "keep [Walter] Carpenter" in Dublin, 1914 June 8.
Letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien about an article by [Mrs O'Hare] and James Larkin's correspondence with [William Dudley] Haywood about a tour and the [Walter] "Carpenter business", 1914 June 15.
Partial letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien about a trip by "Campbell" and or [Tom?] "Johnson", 1914 July 23.
Telegram from James Connolly to William O'Brien saying "Advise postponement of trip in Belfast Sunday", 1914 August 15.
Telegram from James Connolly to William O'Brien saying "Wired you Waterford advising postponement of trip", 1914 August 16.
Telegram from James Connolly to William O'Brien saying "No Lehane letters here yet", 1914 August 17.
Telegram from James Connolly to William O'Brien saying "No Lehane letters here yet explain", 1914 August 18.
Letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien advising that he is about to resign from the Irish Labour Party in Belfast and about the abandonment of meetings during World War I, 1914 August 22.
Letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien stressing the importance of keeping appointments to foster confidence and co-operation, and about some districts acting upon their own initiative, 1914 September 5.
Telegram from James Connolly to William O'Brien saying "Am anxious for word from Dan about that matter", 1914 September 5.
Telegram from James Connolly to William O'Brien saying "You delayed news probable date too long notice Tuesday do wire Fennel hotel Sligo Connolly", 1914 September 5.
Telegram from James Connolly to William O'Brien saying "Will be in Ballymote Monday", 1914 September 5.
Telegram from James Connolly to William O'Brien saying "Will arrive six Wednesday evening", 1914 September 7.
Telegram from James Connolly to William O'Brien saying "Arrive Dublin six Wednesday wire acknowledgement", 1914 September 8.
Postcard from James Connolly to William O'Brien advising that a train arrives at Amiens St at 5.30pm, 1914 September 8.
Lettercard from James Connolly to William O'Brien informing him that he plans to stay out of events around a committee resignation and meeting, and asking to meet O'Brien, 1914 September 10.
Telegram from James Connolly to William O'Brien saying "Arrive Dublin five thirty Connolly", 1914 September 22.
Telegram from James Connolly to William O'Brien saying "Jim is appointing Daly in charge of union see [Thomas] Foran am writing you", 1914 October 5.
Letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien suggesting how to handle James Larkin's intention that Connolly look after "the paper and the insurance" while [P. T.] Daly takes charge of the Irish Transport and General Workers' Union, [1914 October 5].
Letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien about what he sees as the likely impact on the Labour movement and the nationalist cause of [P.T.] Daly leading the Irish Transport and General Workers' Union, 1914 October 7
Letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien asking O'Brien to speak at a meeting to seek wage increases for port labourers, 1915 February 12.
Partial letter from James Connolly [to William O'Brien?] about a cross- America trip that could be undertaken by "O'Carroll" or "Daly", undated.
Partial letter from James Connolly [to William O'Brien?] about Connolly's views on home rule for Ireland and his suggestions for a number of meetings in Belfast, undated.
Letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien in which he writes of having been "driven forth [out of Ireland] by the "Socialists"", undated.
Copy of letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien asking that he make appropriate enquiries in relation to gas money and an acquaintance's stories about monies found, and thanking O'Brien for his help in embarassing circumstances related to a suit of clothes, 1902 June 7.
Copy of letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien in which he states his willingness to resign from the [Irish Socialist Republican] Party if O'Brien will continue in it, 1903 March 21.
Copy of letter from James Connolly [to William O'Brien, Financial Secretary,Irish Socialist Republican Party] seeking payment for days worked for the Irish Socialist Republican Party and about a notice about his resignation to be printed in "the paper" [‘ Workers' Republic'], [1903 March].
Copy of circular from John J. Lyng and others inviting members to join a Socialist organisation in the United States and to attend its inauguration in March, [1907 January].
Copy of letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien about [Daniel] De Leon's "attack on me", the setting up of the [Irish Socialist Federation] and the upcoming International Socialist Congress, 1907 April 15.
Copy of letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien enclosing money for subscriptions and requesting at least 500 copies of a pamphlet, 1907 May 20.
Partial copy of letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien expressing a desire to move back to Ireland but recognising the financial costs of moving with his family, 1909 May 24.
Copy of letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien and others, thanking them for their efforts to get Connolly a position in Ireland, expressing his disappointment at that failure, and outlining his ideas for trade unionism in Ireland, 1909 July 5.
Copy of letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien about his position as national organiser for the Socialist Party of America, the possibility of his return to Ireland, his "plan of action for Ireland", and his hopes to have 'Labour in Irish history' published in London, 1909 September 12.
Copy of letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien proposing how 'The Harp' might be printed in Dublin, which would enable him to move back to Dublin to take care of it, 1909 October 3.
Text of postcard from James Connolly to William O'Brien promising a copy of a manuscript and enquiring whether O'Brien has abandoned "the other matter" [of enabling Connolly to return to Ireland], 1909 October 20.
Copy of letters and advertisements from James Connolly promoting 'The Harp', for William O'Brien to forward to socialist publications, [1909 November 03].
Copy of letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien seeking acknowledgment of the receipt of books sent by Connolly to the Socialist Party of Ireland, and requesting weekly copies of the 'Freemason' and the 'Independent', 1909 November 19.
Copy of letter from James Connolly to the manager of the 'Irish Nation' providing copy for the January [1908?] issue of 'The Harp' and making arrangements for its printing since he has "resolved to give up the contract", 1909 December 1.
Copy of letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien about copy for 'The Harp', Connolly's possible return to Ireland "for the cause" and elaborating on his views for trade unions in Ireland, 1909 December 6.
Copy of letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien attempting to clarify Connolly's intentions in transferring the printing and publishing of 'The Harp' to Dublin regardless of whether Connolly himself returns to Ireland, 1909 December 18.
Copy of letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien re-iterating his desire to have 'The Harp' published in Ireland and informing O'Brien about an offer he has made to the 'Irish Nation', and explaining his reasons for not making a trip to Ireland, 1909 December 20.
Copy of letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien stating that he is considering an "experimental trip" to Ireland prompted by the offer of a job elsewhere, and expressing his satisfaction on hearing that [James] Larkin will manage 'The Harp', 1910 March 7.
Copy of letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien confirming that he will be in Dublin in the last week of July, about where he will travel within Ireland and Britain and how his trip will be publicised, and expressing a preference that [James] Larkin be involved in organising Connolly's tour, [1910] May 3.
Copy of letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien enclosing subscription money for 'The Harp' and requesting a statement of account before sending more, and about his proposed trip to Ireland in July, 1910 May 14.
Copy of letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien asking if 'The Harp' is "alive or dead" as the May issue has not been received and asking about subscription monies he sent to Dublin that have not been acknowledged, 1910 May 29.
Copy of letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien explaining why he wrote previously to O'Brien instead of to [James] Larkin, about the Belfast portion of Connolly's trip to Ireland and Connolly's attitude to the Irish Independent Labour Party, and about his reply to Father Kane, 1910 June 6.
Copy of letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien about James Larkin's imprisonment, matters related to Connolly's upcoming lecture tour in Ireland and Britain, and the continued non-arrival of 'The Harp', 1910 June 24.
Text of postcard from James Connolly to William O'Brien reassuring O'Brien that he does not hold him responsible for circumstances, 1910 July 14.
Copy of telegram from James Connolly to William O'Brien to advise that his ship has landed [from the United States] and he will be in Dublin at 1[pm?] on Tuesday, 1910 July 26.
Copy of letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien asking why he has not been paid monies due to him, and asking about the prices of buttons and for an account with future materials, [1910 August].
Copy of letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien expressing hope that Connolly's tour has been seen as a success, promoting support for new branches, advising that Belfast people want a conference in Dublin, and declining an offer of employment as an organiser in Ireland, 1910 September 5.
Copy of letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien informing him that Belfast comrades plan to visit Dublin on September [18?] and urging Dublin to receive them well for the first such Socialist gathering in Ireland, 1910 September 12.
Copy of letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien about a conference in Dublin for comrades visiting from Belfast, 1910 September 16.
Copy of letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien advising that he is making plans to return to America and asking if there is enough business in Ireland to justify him travelling from Queenstown [Cobh], 1910 September 20.
Copy of letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien requesting copies of 'Labour', asking about the conference [in Dublin for Belfast comrades] and asking O'Brien to let him know about James Larkin's intentions after his release from prison, 1910 September 27.
Copy of letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien outlining his ideas as to how Connolly might work in Ireland and be paid, enclosing a statement to members, and giving his opinion about his possible employment with the Irish Transport Workers' Union for O'Brien to communicate to James Larkin, 1910 October 2.
Copy of letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien requesting pamphlets and enquiring about stock and reprinting of same, 1910 October 5.
Copy of letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien on learning of the failure of his proposal to consider the establishment of an organiser's fund, his unwillingness to go on the payroll [of the Irish Transport and General Workers' Union], and his belief that Irish socialists must fight elections, 1910 October 11.
Text of a postcard from James Connolly to William O'Brien asking that O'Brien not pursue the idea of a trip by Connolly to Dublin and Cork as Connolly does not wish to risk a delay to his return to America, 1910 October 12.
Text of postcard from James Connolly to William O'Brien saying "Your letter received. All right, go ahead", 1910 October 24.
Text of postcard from James Connolly to William O'Brien about an appeal in 'Forward' that money be sent to O'Brien, 1910 October 31.

Letter from James Connolly to an unidentified recipient enclosing money and stating that he has not had any acknowledgement of the various communications he has sent to Ireland, 1902 October 9.
Letter from James Connolly to an unnamed recipient about a row in Troy, New York over the number of nights on which Connolly would speak, and contrasting the Socialist Labour Party and the Social Democratic Federation, 1902 October 16.
Letter from James Connolly to an unnamed recipient urging action to prepare for Dublin elections in which Connolly might be a candidate, with copy of a letter [from Thomas J. Lyng?] to James Connolly on the same subject, 1902 October 22.
Letter from James Connolly to an unnamed recipient stressing the importance of publishing an election address by Connolly, and expressing displeasure at a letter sent to the Socialist Labour Party of America about the expenses of Connolly's tour of the United States, [1902] December 4.
Letter from James Connolly to an unnamed recipient about the 'Workers' Republic' and election work in Dublin, 1902 October 29.
Partial letter from James Connolly to an unnamed recipient expressing annoyance at a delay in issuing the 'Workers' Republic', 1902 November 3.
Letter from James Connolly to an unnamed recipient about Connolly contesting an election in Dublin, 1902 November 28.
Letter from James Connolly to an unnamed recipient about a delay in the publication of the 'Workers' Republic' and asking about the publication of his address for an election in Dublin, 1902 December 9.
Letter from James Connolly [to Thomas J. Lyng] about the sale of literature, the question of "continuing the paper", and Connolly's proposal to form "reading circles" to encourage subscribers outside Dublin, 1902 April 15.
Letter from James Connolly to an unnamed recipient about the delay in the publication of the 'Workers' Republic' and his travel plans for his return to Dublin, 1902 December 20.
Letter from James Connolly [to John J. Lyng] about a riot at Foster Place, and proposing how Dublin might print the 'Workers' Republic' and 'The Socialist' and how the Irish Socialist Republican Party might work with a similar party in Scotland, 1903 May 1.
Letter from James Connolly to "Jack" [John J. Lyng] expressing shock at news from Ireland and asking "is the party dead", 1903 May 15.
Letter from James Connolly [to John J. Lyng] about the current status of the socialist movement in Ireland and his belief that someone needs to take the lead to improve matters, 1903 May 26.
Letter from James Connolly [to John J. Lyng] enclosing his contribution to "whatever fund is at present on the field for party purposes" and expressing a hope that efforts to re-organise the Irish Socialist Republican Party are being made, 1903 June 2
Partial letter from James Connolly [to Murtagh Lyng] requesting copies of the 'Workers' Republic' and about the running of Thomas J. Lyng as an election candidate in Dublin, 1901 June 11.
Partial letter from James Connolly to an unnamed recipient asking why a bundle of the 'Workers' Republic' has not been delivered to Edinburgh, [1902?].
Partial letter from James Connolly to an unnamed recipient seeking reassurance that the 'Workers' Republic' has been distributed to branches, and proposing a card to be used to sign up subscribers in the United States, [1902].

Lott and William Barnes of the National Sailors' and Firemen's Union to William O'Brien, secretary of the Strike Fund of the Dublin Trades Council stating unless it is agreed to raise lockout pay from 5 to 10 shillings a week their members will consider themselves free to return to work, 1914 January 2.

McIntyre, secretary of the Dublin Branch of the Friendly Society of Iron Mongers, to William O'Brien secretary of the Strike Committee, for the Dublin Trades Council informing him that their locked out union members are returning to work at Tonge & Taggart tomorrow, 1914 January 10.
Letter from Frank Smithies, convenor for the Dublin Distress Committee of the Edinburgh and District Trades Council to the Secretary of the Dublin Trades Council requesting an update on the position of the lockout in Dublin, 1914 February 11.
Letter from J.G. Carne, secretary for the Letchworth & District Trades & Labour Council to John Farren of the Dublin Distress Fund of the Dublin Trades Council, enclosing a cheque and asking for an account of the current situation in Dublin, 1914 February 12.
Letter from T. Irwin, secretary of the Dublin Operatives Plasterers' Trade Society, Trades Hall, Capel Street, to William O'Brien or John Farren with the number of union members locked out and asking for financial assistance to provide lockout pay, 1913 January 6.
Letter from J. Black, secretary of the Dublin branch of the National Amalgamated Society of Operative House and Ship Painters & Decorators, to the Dublin Trades Council with a list of union members that cannot receive state unemployment benefit due to the Dublin Lockout dispute, 1913 November 3.
Letter from Walter Halls, organising secretary for the National Union of Railwaymen, Nottingham to William O'Brien, regarding support and financial assistance for the Dublin Trades Council during the Dublin Lockout, 1913 November 23.
Letter from George Waugh, assistant secretary to the Dublin district of the Central Ironmoulders' Association, to the Dublin Trades Council requesting boots and clothing for the children of 18 union men locked out of Hammond Lane Foundry, 1913 December 20

Copy of letter from Francis Sheehy-Skeffington to William O'Brien, informing him that he can no longer speak at a Labour demonstration the following day, as he cannot support a resolution demanding the retention of medical benefits the Insurance Act, 1913 May 24.
Annotated draft statement by J[ames] C[onnolly] for the employee representatives of a Special Joint Conciliation Committee between unions and employers aiming to resolve the Dublin Lockout dispute, circa 1913.

Draft letter from William O'Brien to the Connolly Memorial Committee informing them that the Irish Transport and General Workers' Union, has an abundance of Connolly's writings which has not been in demand, 1933 May.

Draft report by William O'Brien regarding a complaint by the Irish Transport and General Worker's Union on the manner in which voting was conducted during negotiations between the United Labourers and the Master Builders Federation, circa 1913.
Notes by William O'Brien on working conditions in Dublin a concise outline of notable events related to the Irish Transport and General Workers Union from 1913 to 1918, undated.
Letter from James Connolly to "Comrade" applying for re-admission to the Irish Socialist Republican Party following his resignation over a dispute related to paying rent for their clubroom, 1903 March 3.
Letter from James Connolly, Glasgow to Michael Rafferty, Dublin offering a proposal to honour subscriptions to the 'Workers' Republic' by substituting it with the newspaper 'The Socialist', 1903 June 10.
Letter from James Connolly, Glasgow, to Michael Rafferty, Dublin, advising him on international affiliations following the split in the Irish Socialist Republican Party, 1903 August 17.
Letter from James Connolly, Edinbugh, to Michael Rafferty, Dublin, apologising for not writing sooner and referring to a postal order for 'The Workers' Republic', 1903.
Letter from James Connolly, Glasgow, to Michael Rafferty, Dublin, informing him that he has sent American pamphlets to him in the Irish Socialist Republican Party and hopes he is still sending 'The Socialist' to their subscribers, 1903.
Letter from James Connolly, New York, to Michael Rafferty, Dublin, querying the current state of the Irish Socialist Republican Party and refers to the substitution of 'The Socialist' for the 'Workers' Republic' for subscribers, 1904 March 16.
Letter from James Connolly, New York, to "Comrade" reiterating his request for copies of the publications of the Irish Socialist Republican Party and responding to a remark doubting Connolly's character in relation to funds from American subscriptions to the 'Workers' Republic', 1904 July 7.
Letters and associated documents on the split in the Irish Socialist Republican Party in 1903, Connolly's resignation and the amalgamation between the Socialist Labour Party and the Irish Socialist Republican Party in 1904, 1903-1904.
Copy of letter from James Connolly to Edward W. Stewart, secretary of the Irish Socialist Republican Party, explaining the reason for his resignation, 1903 February.

Letter from John Lyng to Bill [William O'Brien] discussing his and James Connolly's resignations from the Irish Socialist Republican Party and encouraging O'Brien to re-join, 1903 March 18.
Letter from John Lyng to [William O'Brien] informing him that the Irish Socialist Republican Party did not recognise or accept his resignation when it was tendered and still consider him a welcome member of the party, 1903 March 18.

Ltd., to James Larkin of the Irish Transport and General Workers' Union refusing to reinstate boatmen that were dismissed for refusing to handle goods associated with scab labour and vehemently defending the treatment and working conditions of Guinness employees, 1913 October 14.
