Bennett, secretary of the Belfast district of the National Sailors' and Firemen's Union, denying him consent to provide the "Innishowen Head" liner a union crew as they still employ scab labour in Dublin and Belfast, 1913 December 13.

Bowerman, secretary of the British Trades Union Congress, Parliamentary Committee, to William O'Brien of the Dublin Trades Council informing O'Brien that unfortunately he cannot increase the amount of financial aid they are providing the Dublin Trades Council to help unions provide lockout pay, 1913 December 29.

Bowerman, secretary of the British Trades Union Congress, Parliamentary Committee, to William O'Brien of the Dublin Trades Council with details of a transfer of money to aid the provision of lockout pay and support for union members and also informing O'Brien on the dire state of the fund, 1914 January 1.
Letter from Charles W. Bowerman, secretary of the British Trades Union Congress, Parliamentary Committee, to William O'Brien of the Dublin Trades Council regarding the drop in donations to the relief fund and their preference to provide food to the women and children of Dublin than lockout pay to the men, 1914 January 9.

Manuscript copies of songs and poems for inclusion in '98 Readings, being a series of reprints of the most important literature current in Ireland 100 years ago, including the chief official documents of the United Irishmen and their writings in prose and verse', a five part publication of reprints of nationalist literature, edited by James Connolly, circa 1898.
Letter from James Connolly to Jack [John J. Lyng] with a draft of the song titled 'When Labour Calls', circa 1903.
Letters to the 'Workers' Republic' from correspondents in the United States of America with subscriptions to the paper following James Connolly's lecture tour, 1902.
Letter from William J. Cassidy, Chicago, to [James Connolly?] informing him of the achievements of socialism in Chicago, asking how the socialist movement in Ireland is faring and asking to meet, 1902 September 24.
Letter from Ernest [Aviyone?], 446 Central Avenue, West Hoboken, New Jersey, to "Comrade" of the Irish Socialist Republican Party, informing him that he was at James Connolly's lecture at Union Hill, New Jersey, and has subscribed to the 'Workers' Republic' to keep in touch with the socialist movement in Ireland, 1902 September 25.
Letter from Timothy McMahon, 520 Lindley Street, Bridgeport, Connecticut, to the Irish Socialist Republican Party congratulating them on having James Connolly to represent themselves and the 'Workers' Republic' to which he has subscribed, 1902 September 25.
Letter from Felix Leonard, 94 Newark St., Providence, Rhode Island, to the Manager of the 'Workers' Republic' enclosing a subscription card for the paper and complementing James Connolly's eloquent lecture in Providence the previous week, 1902 September 30.
Letter from Jeremiah Devine, North Abington, Massachusetts, to "Comrade", Manager of the 'Workers' Republic' commending the work of James Connolly during his lecture tour of the United States and remarking that he will help the Socialist Labour Party of America to establish a Socialist Republic in America, 1902 October 2.
Letter from Charles A. Stromdahl, 52 Taylor St., [Metheun?], Massachusetts, to the Irish Socialist Republican Party, subscribing to the 'Workers' Republic' following a lecture by James Connolly in Boston, 1902 October.
Letter from 'The People', New York, to the 'Workers Republic', Dublin, requesting subscriptions for Fred, H. Brune, Charles C. Crawford, John Donaghue and Leon Lacoste and informing them that they have credited their account with the subscription fees, 1902 October 3.
Letter from Jeremiah Devine, North Abington, Massachusetts, to "Comrade", Editor of the 'Workers' Republic' enclosing a subscription, advertising cards and an article in relation to James Connolly's lecture (not extant), and discussing the relationship between socialism and the Catholic Church in Ireland and the United States, 1902 October 6.
Letter from A.L. Fricke, 167 Washington Street, West Hoboken, New Jersey, to the Irish Socialist Republican Party informing them of their current progress with a coal strike and the "Kangaroo" faction of the Socialist Labor Party, and complementing James Connolly's lecture in New Jersey, 1902 October 12.
Letter from John Walsh, 519 Greenwich St., New York, to the 'Worker's Republic', Dublin, correcting his address in relation to his subscription to the paper, and also discussing James Connolly's lecture tour in the United States, 1902 October 16.
Letter from M. Sullivan, 100 Braniard Street, Detroit, Michigan, to the manager of the 'Workers' Republic', Dublin, regarding a subscription and James Connolly's visit to Detroit, 1902 October 20.
Letter from James H. Arnold, agent at Subscription Book and Bible Publishing Co., 3314 Bank Street, Louisville, Kentucy, to the 'Workers' Republic', Dublin, regarding subscriptions to the paper, and complementing James Connolly's lecture in Louisville, 1902 October 21.
Letter from 'The People', New York, to the 'Workers Republic', 6 Lower Liffey Street, Dublin, requesting subscriptions for J.E. Madison, David Davidson, Charles Zolot and W.H. Peak and informing them that they have credited their account with the subscription fees, 1902 October 24.
Letter from [L. Hansen?], lit[erary?] agent, 149 Souder Avenue, Columbus, Ohio, to "Com[rade]" of the Irish Socialist Republican Party regarding James Connolly's lecture in Columbus and commending him for the work he is doing for the "international solidarity" of socialism, 1902 October 24.
Letter from 'The People', New York, to the 'Workers Republic', 6 Lower Liffey Street, Dublin, requesting annual subscriptions for Fred Lechner and J. Kumpitsch and informing them that they have credited their account with the subscription fees, 1902 October 31.
Letter from Robert MacDonagh, Mulanphy Hospital, St. Louis, Missouri, to "Comrade" of the 'Workers' Republic' enclosing two subscription cards for the paper (not included) which they purchased from James Connolly at his lecture in St. Louis, 1902 November 1.
Letter from Charles G. Davidson, St. Paul, Minnesota, to the 'Workers' Republic', Dublin, regarding a subscription to the paper, 1902 November 5.
Letter from James McPartlin, St. Paul, Minnesota, to the 'Workers' Republic', Dublin, enclosing his subscription card (not extant) for the paper, 1902 November 5.
Letter from J. H. Ecklund, West Superior, Wisconson, to the 'Workers' Republic', 6 Lower Liffey St, Dublin, reegarding James Connolly's speech in Duluth, Minnesota on 1st Nov. and Ecklund's subscription to the paper, 1902 November 7.
Letter from [J. Emoir?], Duluth, Minnesota, to the 'Workers' Republic', Dublin, enclosing a subscription card to the paper (not included), and complementing James Connolly's speech in Duluth, 1902 November 8.
Letter from P.E. Nelson, 1642 Major Ave., Salt Lake City, Utah, to the 'Workers' Republic', Dublin, enclosing a subscription card to the paper (not included), 1902 November 11.
Letter from an unidentified sender in Chicago, Illinois, to the 'Workers Republic', Dublin, enclosing a subscription card to the paper (not included), and discussing the socialist movement in the United States and Ireland, 1902 November 13.
Letter from 'The People', New York, to the 'Workers Republic', Dublin, requesting annual subscriptions for William Doran and John White and informing them that they have credited their account with the subscription fees, 1902 November 15.
Letter from 'The People', New York, to the 'Workers Republic', Dublin, requesting annual subscription for H. Harvey Stuart, Hopewell, Hill, New Brunswick, Canada, and enclosing a receipt for subscriptions received from T. J. Lyng, 1902 November 21.
Letter from Meiko Meyer, for 'The Wage Worker', 334 Arnott St., Detroit, Michigan, to the 'Workers' Republic', Dublin, enlcosing a subscription card for the paper (not included) and hoping to receive it in exchange for their paper, 1902 November 24.
Letter from Stephen Bailey, Delta, Colarado, to the 'Workers' Republic', Dublin, enclosing five new subscription cards for the paper following James Connolly's lecture in Delta, Colorado, 1902 December 5.
Letter from S.B. Hutchinson, Grand Junction, Colorado, to the 'Workers' Republic', Dublin, enclosing twelve subscription cards (not included) to the paper following James Connolly's lecture on 4th December in Grand Junction, 1902 December 6.
Letter from J.M. Long, Waterv[a]liet, New York, to the Irish Socialist Republican Party, complementing James Connolly's lecture tour in the United States and pledging that he and the Socialist Labor Party of America will do what they can "to break the chains of wage slavery" in the United States, 1902 December 20.
Subscription cards for the 'Workers' Republic' from subscribers in the United States and Canada following James Connolly's lecture tour in the United States, circa 1902.
Empty envelope with inscription "Letters Rec. from U.S.A. by I[rish] Soc[ialist] Rep[ublican] P[ar]ty Sept-Dec 1902 about Tour of James Connolly", undated.
Letters regarding the travel arrangements for James Connolly lecture tour of the United States and Canada from Socialist Labor Party of America organisers, secretaries and literary agents aiding Connolly secure subscriptions the 'Workers' Republic', 1902.
List of contributors to a fund to support James Connolly's lecture tour of the United States by the Irish Socialist Republican Party, 1902.
Preliminary itinerary for James Connolly's lecture tour of the United States for September and October in New York, New Jersey, Rhode Island, Conneticut and Massachusetts, 1902.
Circular letter from Daniel O'Brien of the Irish Socialist Republican Party to members who promised donations to fund James Connolly's lecture tour of the United States, requesting that they pay their promised subscriptions, 1902 [June?].
Letter from Henry Kuhn, Socialist Labor Party of America, to Mark Deering, Irish Socialist Republican Party, regarding the organisation of James Connolly's lecture tour of the United States, 1902 June 27.
Letter from Henry Kuhn, Socialist Labor Party of America, to Mark Deering, Irish Socialist Republican Party, regarding Connolly's requests to have a lecture organised for him in San Francisco and the printing of his pamphlets by the Socialist Labor Party of America, 1902 July 30.
Letter from Francis B. Ca[rr?], 80 Page St., Keene, New Hampshire, to J.E.C. Donnelly, New York, informing him that they can accomodate James Connolly for two lectures on the 14th and 15th August and asking when he arrives as to meet him at the train, 1902 August 7.
Letter from Thomas T. Hands, 93 Burnside St., Providence, Rhode Island, to Henry Kuhn, New York, regarding travel arrangements for James Connollly's visit and proposed lectures, 1902 September 23.
Letter from Laurence A. Boland, a Socialist Labor Party organiser in Troy, New York, to James Connolly outlining his travel arrangements and lecture times during his time in Troy, New York, 1902 October 8.
Letter from Michael T. [Benny?], 14 Hancock St., Haverhill, Massachusetts, to James Connolly, Troy, New York, enclosing a copy of the report of the Lynn Socialist Labor Party branch meeting (not included), following his lecture in Lynn, Massachusetts, 1902 October 9.
Letter from Charles G. Davidson, St. Paul, Minnesota, to Henry Kuhn, New York, regarding rearranging James Connolly's visit to St. Paul, to accomodate a proposed social supper on election day, 4th November, and a typescript note from Kuhn to Connnolly on verso asking if he can accept the invitation, 1902 October 10.
Letter from James Matthews, organiser for the Socialist Labor Party of America, Cleveland section, to James Connolly, arranging to meet Connolly at the train station in Collinswood during his lecture tour of the United States and informing him that he will be wearing a "red button" on the lapel of his coat, 1902 October 11.
Letter from [John?] Keegan, 3443 South Halsted St., Chicago, Illinois, to James Matthews, organiser for the Socialist Labor Party of America, Cleveland section, asking him to inform James Connolly that John Keegan would like to meet him and "talk about the comrades in the old town" if he is still visiting Chicago on his lecture tour, 1902 October 14.
Letter from Charles G. Davidson, St. Paul, Minnesota, to James Connolly, St. Louis, Missouri, asking him to deliver a speech at a supper that has been organised for him in the Globe Hotel, St. Paul, Minnesota, during his lecture tour of the United States, 1902 October 24.
Letter from Henry Sale, 43 Ashland Boulivard, Chicago, to James Connolly, regarding travel arrangments for his visit to Chicago on his lecture tour of the United States, and informing him he will wear the "red button of the S.L.P." at the train station, 1902 October 25.
Letter from Joseph H. Sweeny, Yonkers, New York, to Henry Kuhn enclosing a cheque (not extant) for subscriptions to the 'Workers' Republic' and remarking he still has 7 subscription cards that he received from James Connolly and will do all he can to fill them, 1902 October 26.
Letter from Charles H. Chase, secretary of the Colorado State Committee of the Socialist Labor Party of America, to James Connolly, providing him with dates and locations in Colorado for his lecture tour and the names and addresses of local organisers that will organising his lectures and accomodation, 1902 November 16.
Letter from Charles Grupp, organiser for the St. Louis Section of the Socialist Labor Party of America, to James Connolly in Denver, Coloarado, informing him that the St. Louis section do not think a lecture from James Connolly would be useful at this time, 1902 November 27.
Letter from W.S. Corbin, National Secretary for the Socialist Labour Party, Dominion of Canada, to James Connolly, asking him to extend his lecture tour of the United States to London, Ontario, Canada and providing him with the names and addresses of individuals that will provide for him, 1902 December 1.
Letter from W.S. Corbin, National Secretary for the Socialist Labour Party, Dominion of Canada, to James Connolly, asking him to extend his lecture tour of the United States to London, Ontario, Canada, 1902 December 2.
Letter from Hugh R. Richards, Indianapolis, Indiana, to James Connolly regarding the need to rearrange his lecture in Marion to Indianapolis and asking Connolly to speak on the socialist movement in America at the lecture, 1902 December 6.
Letter from Hugh R. Richards, Indianapolis, Indiana, to James Connolly reiteraring a previous letter in case he did not receive it, regarding the need to rearrange his lecture in Marion to Indianapolis and infomrs him on the advertising for the lecture, 1902 December 7.
Letter from James Whipp to James Connolly, regarding a picture he bought in Fall River during his visit as part of his lecture tour, the outcome of a local election, and Connolly's plans to extend his tour to Canada, 1902 December 8.
Letter from Denis McGoff to James Connolly enclosing 2 subscriptions to the 'Workers' Republic' and 4 unused subscription cards (not included), complementing his lecture in New Bedford, and wishing him a merry Christmas, 1902 December 8.
Letter from Meiko Meyer to James Connolly, requesting that he come to Detroit early for interviews with capitalist newspapers and informing him that he has begun advertising for the meeting, 1902 December 14.
Letter from L. Abelson, Organiser for the Socialist Labor Party, New York Section, to James Connolly regarding arrangements for Connolly's last lectures in New York before he concludes his lecture tour, 1902 December 16.
Letter from Charles Woodley to James Connolly, enclosing a copy of letter from Meiko Meyer about Connolly's travel arrangements for his lecture in Detroit, 1902 December 16.
Letter from Joseph H. Sweeny to Henry Kuhn, enclosing cheque for subscriptions and five empty subscription cards for the 'Workers' Republic' which he attempted to fill for James Connolly following his lectures in New York, 1902 December 17.
Letter from W.S. Corbin, National Secretary for the Socialist Labour Party, Dominion of Canada, to James Connolly enclosing a cheque for $28.50 (not included), and informing him that they were very pleased with his visit to Canada, 1902 December 18.
Letter from Percy Kemp, Literary Agent for Socialist Labor Party, Dominion of Canada, Toronto Section to an unidentified recipient of the Socialist Labor Party of America enclosing payment for three annual subscriptions to the 'Workers' Republic' (not included), 1902 December 23.
Letter from the White Star Line, New York, to James Connolly, Troy, New York, advising him that the "Cymric" does not have his requested "second saloon" and hoping he has secured passage to Ireland on the "Celtic", at the conclusion of his lecture tour of the United States and Canada, 1902 December 23.
Letters from M.D. Fitzgerald to James Connolly, mainly concerning personal matters inlcuding his financial difficulties, 1902-1907.
Letter from M.D. Fitzgerald, 49 Roxbury St., Boston, Massachusetts, to Henry Kuhn, National Secretary of the Socialist Party of America, enclosing payment for annual subscriptions to the 'Workers' Republic' (not included), secured following James Connolly's lecture, 1902 October 13.
Letter from M.D. Fitzgerald, Boston, Massachusetts, to James Connolly, advising him on his job search and emigration to the United States, and discussing Fitzgerald's job in insurance, 1903 November 10.
Letter from M.D. Fitzgerald, Boston, Massachusetts, to James Connolly, informing him that he has transfered Connolly's insurance to Troy, New York; discussing his workload, and hoping Connnolly is soon reunited with his family, 1904 April 14.
Letter from M.D. Fitzgerald, Hoboken, New Jersey, to James Connolly, regarding his new job in Hoboken; his financial difficulties and asking about Connolly's family, 1906 May 2.
Letter from M.D. Fitzgerald, New Jersey, to James Connolly, asking for the money Connolly owes him plus an additional £5 to help get him out of his "financial hole", 1907 September 23.
Letter from M.D. Fitzgerald, 308 W. 154th St., New Jersey, to James Connolly, regarding his financial difficulties, his late fees for the Socialist Labor Party of America and asking Connolly for the money he owes him, circa 1907.
Letters from Henry Kuhn, National Secretary of the the Socialist Labour Party of the United States of America, to the Irish Socialist Republican Party and James Connolly regarding the planning of, and travel arrangements for Connolly's lecture tour of the United States and Canada, 1899-1902.
Letter from Henry Kuhn, National Secretary of the Socialist Labor Party of America, to Murtha[gh] J. Lyng, Assistant Secretary of the Irish Socialist Republican Party, agreeing to aid in the distibution of a leaflet to locations visited by Irish socialists, 1899 September 21.
Letter from Henry Kuhn, National Secretary of the Socialist Labor Party of America, to T.J. Lyng, Secretary of the Irish Socialist Republican Party, acknowledging receipt of circulars that arrived to late for a meeting in New York but have been distributed to New York, Boston and Providence, 1899 October 24.
Letter from Henry Kuhn, National Secretary of the Socialist Labor Party of America, to W.J. Bradshaw of the Irish Socialist Republican Party, regarding funds for the 'Workers' Republic', circular leaflets that Kuhn is to distribute, and describing the "hot and lively affair" that is the election campaign in the 16th district of New York, 1899 October 31.
Letter from Henry Kuhn, National Secretary of the Socialist Labor Party of America, to Murtha[gh] J. Lyng, Secretary for the Irish Socialist Republican Party, regarding their new venture issuing a daily paper the 'Daily People' and refusing to commit to receiving James Connolly for a lecture tour of the United States, 1900 July 14.
Letter from Henry Kuhn, National Secretary of the Socialist Labor Party of America, to Murtha[gh] J. Lyng, Secretary for the Irish Socialist Republican Party, explaining that an Irish socialist agitator would not receive the same reception in America as an Irish nationalist agitator, and remarking that New York is not ready for the new 'Daily People', 1900 September 1.
Letter from Julian Pierce, Manager of the New York Labor News Company, to Murtha[gh] J. Lyng, Secretary for the Irish Socialist Republican Party, regarding the publication of an article titled the "Economic Future of Ireland" and the popularity of 'Erin's Hope', 1901 November 14.
Letter from Henry Kuhn, National Secretary of the Socialist Labor Party of America, to Mark Deering, Secretary for the Irish Socialist Republican Party, informing them that the Socialist Labor Party is now in a position to consider the proposed lecture tour of a member of the Irish Socialist Republican Party and requesting clarification on details on same, 1902 April 10.
Letter from Henry Kuhn, National Secretary of the Socialist Labor Party of America, to James Connolly, regarding travel arrangements, organising dates, his laundry and the importance of reporting his lectures to the 'Daily People' to retain interest in the tour, 1902 September 30.
Letter from Henry Kuhn, National Secretary of the Socialist Labor Party of America, to James Connolly, outlining the arrangements of dates and locations for lectures in and en route to San Francisco, California, and Connolly's request for the arrangment of some personal days there, 1902 October 18.
Letter from Henry Kuhn, National Secretary of the Socialist Labor Party of America, to James Connolly, suggesting that he still travel to Chicago regardless of their section's inabiltiy to arrange a meeting, and including names and addresses of representatives in Minnesota and Illinois to clarify travel arrangements, 1902 October 20.
Letter from Henry Kuhn, National Secretary of the Socialist Labor Party of America, to James Connolly, regarding financial support during Connolly's lecture tour, subscription cards for the 'Workers' Republic' and organising some dates for lectures in Canada, 1902 October 24.
Letter from Henry Kuhn, National Secretary of the Socialist Labor Party of America, to James Connolly, subscription cards for the 'Workers' Republic' and a retraction to an insulting statement made by "Passono" at the outset of a meeting at which Connolly was speaking in Troy, New York, 1902 October 31.
Letter from Henry Kuhn, National Secretary of the Socialist Labor Party of America, to Charles H. Chase, Secretary to the Colorado State Committee of the Socialist Labor Party of America, asking Chase to provide him with dates and locations for James Connolly's lectures in Colorado to allow enough time to make travel arrangements, 1902 November 13.
Letter from Henry Kuhn, National Secretary of the Socialist Labor Party of America, to Daniel O'Brien, Secretary to the Irish Socialist Republican Party, regarding James Connolly's success in securing subscriptions for the 'Workers' Republic' and informing him that Connolly will depart from New York for Ireland on Dec 27th on the "Cunarder Eturia", 1902 December 8.
Letter from Henry Kuhn, National Secretary of the Socialist Labor Party of America, to James Connolly, informing him that he has booked him passage from New York for Ireland on Dec 27th on the "Cunard steamer Eturia", 1902 December 8.
Letter from Henry Kuhn, National Secretary of the Socialist Labor Party of America, to James Connolly, regarding a letter of accusation that Daniel De Leon is holding for him and arrangements for Connolly's final days in the United States, 1902 December 18.
Letter from Henry Kuhn, National Secretary of the Socialist Labor Party of America, to James Connolly, regarding a misunderstanding related to Connolly's salary at the conclusion of the lecture tour and his departure date, 1902 December 20.
Partial letter from Henry Kuhn, National Secretary of the Socialist Labor Party of America, to James Connolly, regarding Connolly's salary and travel arrangments for his lecture tour in the United States and Canada, and plans for a farewell reception in New York, 1902.
Correspondence of the Socialist Labor Party of the United States of America related to party politics, James Connolly, and the role of the National Secretary and the National Executive Committee, 1907.
Copy of minutes of meetings of the National Executive Committee of the Socialist Labor Party on 6th and 7th January 1907 regarding financial and administrative affairs and a complaint made against the National Secretary, Frank Bohn, 1907 January 6-7.
Letter from Frank Bohn, National Secretary of the Socialist Labor Party, to the members of the National Executive Committee, asking them to vote on a proposed resolution regarding the distribtuion of the minutes of their meetings, 1907 January 29.
Letter from William Teichlauf, Secretary of an Investigation Committee of the Socialist Labor Party, to James Connolly, requesting specific statements about his complaint, 1907 March 16.
Copies of letter from James Connolly to William Teichlauf, Secretary of an Investigation Committee of the Socialist Labor Party, outlining the nature of his complaint about the conduct of members of the Socialist Labor Party, 1907 [March?].
Copy of letter from Charles H. Chase to the members of the National Executive Committee of the Socialist Labor Party, regarding his resignation from the "party plant" and the discord between himself and the Sub-Committee of the National Executive Committee of the Socialist Labor Party, 1907 March 16.
Open circular letter from Daniel De Leon to members of the Socialist Labor Party, responding to an enquiry from William Teichlauf, Secretary of an Investigation Committee of the Socialist Labor Party regarding a formal complaint made by James Connolly, 1907 March 29.
Copy of circular letter form Frank Bohn, National Secretary of the Socialist Party, to the members of the National Executive Committee, regarding the financial situation of the party following a libel court case against 'The People', 1907 April 10.
Partial copy of letter from Olive M. Johnson, member of the National Executive Committee of the Socialist Labor Party, to its members, motioning for the removal of the Sub-Committee of the National Executive Committee and outlining the charges, 1907 April 24.
Copy of response by the Sub-Committee of the National Executive Committee of the Socialist Labor Party, defending themselves against charges in a letter from Olive M. Johnson, member of the National Executive Committee of the Socialist Party, motioning for the removal of the Sub-Committee, 1907 April 26.
Copy of letter of complaint by Charles H. Chase and Julias Eck regarding the conduct of the Sub Committee of the National Executive Committee of the Socialist Labor Party in relation to their handling of "Gilchrist" and Chase's complaints, 1907 April 26.
Copy of letter from "John Kircher", 3087 West 100th Street, Cleveland, Ohio, to Frank Bohn, National Secretary of the Socialist Labor Party of America, enquiring about plans to meet a financial debt from a libel court case, 1907 April 30.
Copy of letter from Frank Bohn, National Secretary of the Socialist Labor Party of America, to the members of the Natiaonl Executive Committee regarding the outcome of a vote one thea mount of delegates for an International Congress and the admission of race federations, 1907 April 30.
Copy of letter from "Peter Jacobson", New York, to the members of the National Executive Committee of the Socialist Labor Party, outlining the efforts of the New York section to raise funds for the financial debt the party was facing, 1907 May 1.
Copy of letter from Frank Bohn, National Secretary of the Socialist Labor Party, to the members of the National Executive Committee of the Socialist Labor Party, enclosing letters with advice on raising funds for the financial debt of the party following the Burnstein libel case, 1907 May 3.
Letter from Frank Bohn, National Secretary of the Socialist Labor Party, to James Connolly regarding the posponement of a meeting to allow Bohn to visit and lecture for the "Hungarian local" of Philadelphia, 1907 May 3.
Letter from Frank Bohn, National Secretary of the Socialist Labor Party, to James Connolly regarding the posponement of a meeting, and asking Connolly to attend after work, informing him that they will only cover important matters when he is present, 1907 May 7.
Letter from Frank Bohn, National Secretary of the Socialist Labor Party, to the members of the National Executive Committee asking for instruction in relation to the ballot on a resolution submitted by Olive M. Johnson, 1907 May 9.
Copy of letter from Charles H. Chase, to the members of the National Executive Committee of the Socialist Labor Party complaining that Frank Bohn refused him access to Sub-Committee records, namely James Connolly's correspondence, 1907 May 9.
Circular letter from Frank Bohn, National Secretary of the Socialist Labor Party, to the members of the National Executive Committee, asking if there a second to a motion from John Kircher to remove James Connolly from the Sub-Committee of the National Executive Committee, 1907 May 23.
Copy of letter from Louis C. Haller, Sectretary of the California State Executive Committee, to the members of the National Executive Committee of the Socialist Labor Party, with copies of letters between Frank Bohn and Olive C. Johnson, endorsing the removal of the Sub-Committee of the National Executive Committee, 1907 May 24.
Circular letter from Frank Bohn, National Secretary of the Socialist Labor Party, to the members of the National Executive Committee, asking for information on candidates for national organisers and touring speakers for the Socialist Labor Party, 1907 May 24.
Letter from Frank Bohn, National Secretary of the Socialist Labor Party, to James Connolly, informing him it is too late to make changes to a circular letter and that Connolly's proposed statement would not "give rise to very much discussion as the quibbling will be too evident", 1907 May 28.
Letter from Frank Bohn, National Secretary of the Socialist Labor Party, to James Connolly, informing him that he has been nomianted as a delegate to the International Socialist Congress at Stuttgart, Germany, 1907 May 28.
Circular letter from Frank Bohn, National Secretary of the Socialist Labor Party, to the members of the National Executive Committee, summarising the minutes of a recent meeting of the Sub-Committee regarding Olive M. Johnson's resolution, 1907 May 30.
Letter from Frank Bohn, National Secretary of the Socialist Labor Party, to "Comrade" [James Connolly] organising a meeting of the Sub-Committee of the National Executive Committee following a request from members to discuss unidentified matters which "require immediate attention", 1907 May 31.
Copy of a circular letter from Frank Bohn, National Secretary of the Socialist Labor Party, to the members of the National Executive Committee, requesting the removal of Charles H. Chase from the Sub-Committee due to his disruptive actions, 1907 June 11.
Copy of a circular letter from Frank Bohn, National Secretary of the Socialist Labor Party, to the members of Socialist Labor Party, requesting funds to aid the party's financial situation following the move of the headquarters in New York and legal fees from an appeal against a libel case from J. Bernstein, 1907.
Copies of a letter from James Connolly to "Comrade" protesting the actions of the New Jersey State Executive Committee of the Socialist Labor Party in removing him as a member of the National Executive Committee, 1907.
Copies of letter from James Connolly to "Comrade" tendering his resignation from his post as the Socialist Labor Party National Executive Committee delegate from New Jersey following complaints from members in New Jersey and charges from Daniel De Leon, 1907.
Copies of letter from James Connolly answering charges brought against him by Daniel De Leon including reference to a theft from the party funds in the Labor News Company, 1907.
Copy of voting card for members of the Socialist Labor Party on resolutions related to the powers of the office of the National Secretary and the role of the Sub-Committee of the National Executive Committee, circa 1907.
Partial list of names and addresses of individuals in the United States, most likely related to the Socialist Labor Party of America, undated.
Letters to James Connolly from correspondents in the United States of America concerning the socialist movement, organising Connolly's lectures across the United States and party politics, 1903-1910 and undated.
Letter from Lazarus Abelson, Organiser for the Socialist Labor Party, to James Connolly requesting a letter to be read at the "Cooper Union Meeting", 1903 June 13.
Letter from John Hossack of the American Transit Company, New York, to James Connolly in Boston, Massachusetts, regarding forwarding a repaired box and laundered clothing to him in Boston, 1903 October 27.
Letter from Lazarus Abelson, Organiser for the Socialist Labor Party, to James Connolly inviting him to speak at a mass meeting at Cooper Union, New York, for International Labor Day, 1904 April 1.
Letter from Lazarus Abelson, Organiser for the Socialist Labor Party, to James Connolly acknowledging Connolly's letter notifying Abelson that he cannot attend a mass meeting at Cooper Union, New York, for International Labor Day and their May Day Celebration, 1904 April 7.
Receipt from Bridget McDonald for "M.O.F", Dorchester, Massachusetts, for James Connolly for $11.50 for "payment in full for branch", 1904 April 12.
Partial letter from an unidentified sender to James Connolly, reagrding his now "better circumstances" and a debate about the comparison between tenement and living conditions in Ireland and the United States, 1904 June 14.
Letter form "[D.S. Ranglien?]", 184 Julian St., Providence, Rhode Island, to James Connolly, clarifying an issue that arose in relation to Connolly only speaking under the auspices of the Socialist Labor Party while in Rhode Island, circa 1904.
Letter form Hugh R. Richards, Indianapolis, to James Connolly, informing him not to worry about payments owed, and asking after Connolly and his family, 1905 April 8.
Memorandum from A[ppleton] P.C. Griffin, Chief Bibliographer of the Library of Congress listing historical sources in answer to James Connolly's request for names of regiments recruited from Illionois and Ohio during the Civil War, 1905 April 27.
Letter from Fred[erick] Fellerman, Secretary of the Connecticut State Executive Committee of the Socialist Labor Party, to James Connolly outlining the job requirements and details of the position of oganiser-solicitor for the states Massachusetts, Connecticut and Rhode Island, 1905 June 26.
Letter from L. Katz, Secretary of the Pennsylvania State Executive Committee of the Socialist Labor Party, to James Connolly offering him a position as organiser and canvasser for party literature in Pennsylvania, 1905 July 24.
Letter from L. Katz, Secretary of the Pennsylvania State Executive Committee of the Socialist Labor Party, to James Connolly enclosing a cheque for £15 (not included) in relation to the organiser position Katz had offered Connolly, 1905 July 28.
Letter from L. Katz, Secretary of the Pennsylvania State Executive Committee of the Socialist Labor Party, to James Connolly informing him that he must retract his job offer as his Committee cannot guarantee funding to pay the salary, 1905 August 2.
Letter from "[A.S. Dowlin?]", Finlay, Texas, to James Connolly advising him on contacts in Texas following an advertisment Connolly placed in the 'Daily People' regarding the Socialist Labor Party, 1905 August 9.
Letter from L. Katz, Secretary of the Pennsylvania State Executive Committee of the Socialist Labor Party, to James Connolly querying why Connolly has not returned a sum of £15 dollars that he owes the Committee and informing him that Katz is being held personally repsonsible for the money, 1905 September 1.
Copy of letter from the Socialist Labor Party and the Italian Socialist Federation to the Chairman and Members of the Police Commissioners of Newark, New Jersey, complaining about the confiscation of red flags from a peaceful parade and the windows of premises of the Italian Socialist Federation, 1905 September 1.
Letter from Hugh R. Richards, Indianapolis, Indiana, to James Connolly expressing relief that Connolly has communicated with him regarding a sum of money that Connolly owes, 1908 July 18.
Letter from Hugh R. Richards, Indianapolis, to James Connolly, acknowledging receipt of payment of part of monies owed, 1906 July 31.
Letter from "R.H. [Buimen?]", Manager of the North American Music Company, New York, to [James Connolly?], regarding a contract for the publication of an anthem, 1907 April 19.
Letter from John Beehler, Financial Secretary to the Brooklyn branch of the Industrial Workers of the World, to James Connoll, replying to his suggestion to re-organise the branch, describing their status and enclosing a list of names and addresses of members, 1907 November 14.
Letter from "N.R. Smith Murray", 72 Appleton St., Providence, Rhode Island, to James Connolly complementing 'The Harp' and enclosing subscriptions (not included) to the paper, 1908 January 7.
Letter from "James Scheuerer", Organiser pro term for the New York Section of the Socialist Labor Party, to James Connolly inviting him to speak at a party meeting at Webster Hall on the 1st May, 1908 April 13.
Circular letter from the administration of the Industrial Workers of the World to its members and supporters, reiterating an appeal for payment of outstanding bills and for financial support from members and local branches to pay debts, 1908 April 26.
Letter from Fred Cederholm, Bridgeport, Connecticut, to an unidentified recipient organising details for a speech by James Connolly at a meeting of the Socialist Party of America in Bridgeport, Connecticut, 1908 July 21.
Letter from Robert J. Kelly, Lowell, Massachusetts, to an unidentified recipient organising details for a speech by James Connolly at a socialist meeting in South Common, Lowell, Massachusetts, 1908 July 21.
Letter from Geo. E. Harris, Leominster, Massachusetts, to an unidentified recipient organising details for a speech by James Connolly at a socialist meeting from the bandstand on the common in Leominster, Massachusetts, 1908 July 21.
Letter from J.D. Williams, Malden, Massachusetts, to James Connolly accepting his offer to visit Malden and speak at a meeting, 1908 July 22.
Letter from J.D. Williams, Malden, Massachusetts, to an unidentified recipient planning details for James Connolly's visit and lecture at a socialist meeting in Malden, Massachusetts, 1908 July 26.
Letter from John F. Molloy, Corresponding Secretary for the Socialist Party Club of Boston, to the manager of 'The Harp' requesting that James Connolly provide a lecture in South Boston, Massachusetts, 1908 August 6.
Partial letter from an unidentified sender in Greenfield, Massachusetts, to James Connolly, informing him that he must cancel Connolly's lecture dates because of a clash with speeches by "Clark of Texas" and other inconveniences, 1908 August 12.
Letter from "James F. Foy", Quincy, Massachusetts, to [James F.] Carey asking for James Connolly to deliver a speech at a meeting of a "crowd of Irish men" at a Hibernian's hall in Quincy, 1908 August 19.
Letter from unidentified author, 741 East 5th St., Brooklyn, New York, to James Connolly enclosing money [not included] to aid Connolly's attendance at the 1908 Convention of the Socialist Party of America in Chicago, Illinois, 1908 September 16.
Letter from J. Mahlon Barnes, National Secretary for the Socialist Party of America, to James Connolly informing Connolly that he has been nominated as a candidate for the National Executive Committee of the Socialist Party of America, 1908 December 1.
Letter from unidentified author, 741 East 5th St., Brooklyn, New York, to James Connolly requesting that he give a lecture at a meeting in New York on January, 1909, 1908 December 17.
Letter from "W.S. McGeoch", 440 St. John St., Portland, Maine, to J.E.C. Donnelly, New York, regarding organising additional lecture dates for James Connolly in Maine, [1908?] July 31.
Letter from Charles H. Kerr, Chicago, to James Connolly outlining the costs of printing and publishing socialist handbills, periodicals and Connolly's book, 1909 March 5.
Letter from Charles H. Kerr, Chicago, to James Connolly enclosing a cheque for Connolly for copyright on his book (not included) and noting advertisment and printing details, 1909 March 15.
Letter from unidentified person to J. [E.] C. Donnelly, New York, requesting that a response be made in 'The Harp' to offset the offence likely to be given to Catholic socailists by an upcoming speech by "Prof. Monaghan", 1909 April 5..
Letter from J. Mahlon Barnes, National Secretary for the Socialist Party of America, to James Connolly informing him that he had communicated with numerous state secretaries to establish an itinerary for a lecture and propaganda tour for Connolly in May, 1909 April 9.
Letter from J. Mahlon Barnes, National Secretary for the Socialist Party of America, to James Connolly enclosing copy of a letter him that he had sent to numerous local offices to establish an itinerary for a lecture and propaganda tour, 1909 April 17.
Letter from "R.B. Stringham", New York, to [James Connolly?] inviting him to attend a meeting of the "Bronx Forum", to discuss the establishment of a centre in the Bronx by members of the Socialist Party of America, 1910 February 14.
Letter from Bernard McMahon, Chicago, to James Connolly, discussing the socialist landscape in Chicago, and refers to the charges against J. Mahlon Barnes, 'The Daily People' and Connolly's new book, 1910 September 14.
Partial letter from the Industrial Workers of the World to James Connolly and other members of the organisation, requesting weekly essays of interest to the working class, undated.
Letter from "John Dailly" to James Connolly regarding his continued unemployment and the political situation in Dorchester, undated.
Letter from the founder of the 'Irish News', a publication in St. Louis, Missouri, to the editor of 'The Harp', New York, [James Connolly?], regarding the failure of the 'Irish News' and some private gossip about a "playwright priest", undated.
Circular letter from the manager of 'The Harp' advertising James Connolly's upcoming lecture tour and asking recipients to confirm dates for meetings in their areas, undated.
Material concerning James Connolly's article 'Wages, marriage and the Church' and letter 'As to race and language organisations', 1904-1907.
Letter from James Connolly to the editor of the 'Daily People' [in relation to Connolly's piece 'Wages, marriage and the Church'], 1904 April.
Transcript of writings in the 'Weekly People' titled "National Convenion, SLP Attititude on Trades Unions", 1904 July 16.
Statement by John J Lyng describing James Connolly's attitude to the Socialist Labor Party of America's Trades' union resolution [of 1904], undated.
Transcript of writings, including correspondence, from the 'Weekly People' on topics including Irish-American newspapers and socialism in Ireland, James Connolly's involvment in various matters related to the Socialist Labor Party [of America] and protests against police actions, 1905-1908.
Transcript of "Wages, marriage and the church, a discussion initated by James Connolly and answered by the editor of 'The People'" as it appeared in the 'Weekly People', with extracts from the editor's reply, 1904 April 9.
Newscutting from the 'Weekly People' of "Wages, marriage and the church, a discussion initated by James Connolly and answered by the editor of 'The People'", 1904 April 9.
Transcript of writings, including correspondence, from the 'Weekly People' in response to James Connolly's 'Wages, marriage and the Church', 1904 April - July 30].
Transcript from the 'Weekly People' of a report of the National Executive Committee of the Socialist Labor Party of America on "our international relations", 1904 July 15.
Newscutting from the 'Weekly People' of a letter on the topic of wages and the editor's reply, 1905.
Newscutting from the 'Weekly People' of a letter on the topic of ""value", "wages" and other things" and the editor's reply, 1906 May 5.
Transcript of a letter from James Connolly to the 'Weekly People' titled "As to race and language organizations", 1907 March 2.
Manuscript draft of two lectures, entitled 'The Connolly controversy' and 'The future of labour', by James Connolly, circa 1904-1908.
Draft of a lecture by James Connolly taking issue with Connolly's public disagreement with Daniel De Leon being described as the "Connolly controversy" and outlining what is at stake for him, De Leon and the Socialist Labor Party of America, undated.
Letters from James Connolly to John Bohan and Peter Keeley concerning the Irish Transport and General Workers Union, 1914-1915.

Copy of letter from James Connolly to Peter Keeley [of the Sligo branch?] acknowledging receipt of £30 and about advances obtained for workers, 1915 May 5.

Copy of letter from James Connolly to Daniel O'Brien about Connolly contesting an election in Dublin, 1902 November 28.

Copy of letter from James Connolly to Daniel O'Brien about the delay in the publication of the 'Workers' Republic' and his travel plans for his return to Dublin, 1902 December 20.
Letters from James Connolly to [James] Keir Hardie concerning the Independent Labour Party and socialist affairs, 1894.

Postcard from James Connolly to T. J. O'Brien [Assistant Secretary, Irish Socialist Republican Party] reminding O'Brien to prepare minutes before a meeting that evening, 1897 July 1.
Letter from James Connolly to Daniel O'Brien seeking a loan for £2 so that Connolly may puchase stock to sell, 1899 March 11.
Incomplete letter from an unidentified author to "Comrade [Edward W?] Stewart" about the end of a crisis in "the Party" and agitation in New York city, 1899 October 29.
Letter from James Connolly [to George S. Yates] in reply to Yates' letter about the late arrival of the January issue of 'The Socialist' and the printing of articles over more than one page, [1903 February].
Circular from John J. Lyng and others inviting members to join a Socialist organisation in the United States and to attend its inauguration in March, [1907 January].
Letter from James Connolly to the Secretary of the ISP [Irish Socialist Party] about the formation of a new organisation of Irish socialists in the United States, and requesting a poem ['The artisans garret'] for use in that organisation's inauguration, 1907 January 28.
Copy of letter from James Connolly to the Secretary of the Irish Socialist Party [Owen C. Cullen] resigning from the National Executive Council of the Party and asking it to "refute the slander" of Daniel De Leon's claim that Connolly's United States tour was "in the interest of the "British movement"", 1907 April 29.
Letter from James Connolly to an unidentified recipient expressing disappointment with a delivery of books, and seeking an Irish correspondent and contributions for a new publication ['The Harp'], 1907 October 3.
Letter from James Connolly to an unnamed recipient expressing regret for having referred to the latter as a contributor the 'The Harp' , 1907 December 26.
Letters and advertisements from James Connolly promoting 'The Harp', for William O'Brien to forward to socialist publications, [1909 November 03].
Letter from James Connolly to R.J. Hoskin thanking him for his assistance, outlining Connolly's recent financial affairs, including an account, and referring to matters in Dublin, Cork and Belfast, 1911 June 14.
Letter from James Connolly [to Edward Lynch?] about a proposition relating to the role of James Connolly at an event in Cork, 1913 April 30.
Letter from James Connolly to James Larkin setting out Connolly's response to Larkin's proposal about sharing responsiblities at the Irish Transport and General Workers' Union during Larkin's absence, 1914 October 9.

Typescript copy of article by James Connolly entitled 'Address to the Delegates' from 'The Irish Worker' in which he lauds the heroes and heroines of the 1913 Lockout and castigates Irish journalists for being "unscrupulous" and "evil-minded", 1914 May 30.
Typescript copy of article by James Connolly entitled 'Our Rulers as a Study' which takes a look at the ruling classes and "the continually accumulating evidences of the unscrupulous methods" by which they "strive to ensure a continuance of their ruling", 1915 Jan. 16.
Typescript copy of article by James Connolly entitled 'Why the Citizen Army honours Rossa' discussing the tribute paid to Jeremiah O'Donovan Rossa by the Irish Citizen Army, 1915 Jul.

Typescript copies of articles from 'The Irish Worker', probably all by James Connolly, 1912 July - 1915 January.
Typescript copy of article by [James Connolly?] entitled 'Wonder of Wonders. The London "Times" tells the truth"' from 'The Irish Worker', 1913 Oct. 11.
Typescript copy of article by James Connolly entitled 'Why not let the bosses appoint our Trade Union officials?' from 'The Irish Worker', 1913 Oct. 18.
Typescript copy of article by [James Connolly?] entitled 'The Individual Liberty of The Bosses' from 'The Irish Worker', 1913 Oct. 25.
Typescript copy of article by James Connolly entitled 'Importation v. Deportation' from 'The Irish Worker' urging the workers to rally on Nov. 10 and attend "a Mass Picket outside the doors or gates of their former employment", 1913 Nov. 8.
Typescript copy of article by James Connolly entitled 'Irish Rebels and English Mobs' from 'The Irish Worker' talking about a gathering in Manchester and the changing attitudes of the working class in that city towards "Irish rebels" since an incident that occurred 46 years before, 1913 Nov. 22.
Typescript copy of article by James Connolly entitled 'Capitalist Dove of Peace' from 'The Irish Worker', 1913 Dec. 6.
Typescript copy of article by James Connolly entitled 'Arms and the Man' from 'The Irish Worker' describing what happened when the I.T.G.W.U. "proposed to organise and drill a Citizen Army of its own", 1913 Dec. 13.
Typescript copy of article by James Connolly entitled 'To the Working Class of Dublin' from 'The Irish Worker', 1913 Dec. 13.
Typescript copy of article by James Connolly entitled 'Home Thrusts' from the 'Irish Worker' recounting the happenings at the Labour Conference that took place in London that week, 1913 Dec. 13.
Typescript copy of article by James Connolly entitled 'A Fiery Cross or Christmas Bells' from 'The Irish Worker', 1913 Dec.
Typescript copy of article by James Connolly entitled 'The "Scabbing" at Dublin', a joint manifesto by James Larkin and James Connolly, 1913 Dec. 31.
Typescript copy of article by James Connolly entitled 'Home Thrusts by Spailpín' from 'The Irish Worker' in which he defends Jim Larkin's mooted fundraising trip to America, 1914 Jan. 14.
Typescript copy of article by James Connolly entitled 'The Labour and the proposed partition of Ireland' from 'The Irish Worker' discussing the recent proposals regarding the settlement of the Home Rule question, 1914 Mar. 14.
Typescript copy of article by James Connolly entitled 'The Head Line' from 'The Irish Worker' which refers to a letter he received from William Barnes of the National Sailors' and Firemen's Union, 1914 Mar. 14.
Typescript copy of article by James Connolly entitled 'The Outrages at Jacob's' in which he expounds on the behaviour of Jacob's manager towards the girls who applied to him for re-employment after the 1913 Lockout was resolved, 1914.
Typescript copy of article by James Connolly entitled 'Ireland upon the Dissecting Table' in which he appeals to the public to protest "against the proposal to allow the unity of Ireland to be placed at the mercy of the voters in a small part of Ireland", 1914 Apr. 18.
Typescript copy of article by James Connolly entitled 'America and Europe' in which he talks about how certain British and Irish press agencies have been telling the public "that In the United States public opinion is practically unanimous on the side of Great Britain and her allies", 1914 Aug. 22.
Typescript copy of article by James Connolly entitled 'The War upon the German Nation' in which he expresses his opinions on John Redmond's policy of sending Irish troops to Gernany in order to show that Ireland "was as one with the empire in this struggle", 1914 Aug. 29.
Typescript copy of article by James Connolly entitled 'Recruiting - Let the Wastrels Go' in which he discusses and denounces the tactics employed by diaboligal agencies in order "to coax, coerce, or seduce Irishmen to enlist to fight the battles of the Empire", 1914 Sept. 5.
Typescript copy of article by James Connolly entitled 'The Friends of Small Nationalists' from 'The Irish Worker', 1914 Sept. 18.
Typescript copy of article by James Connolly entitled 'Ruling by Fooling' in which he gives his thoughts on "the Great Debate on Home Rule", 1914 Sept. 14.
Typescript copy of article by James Connolly entitled 'Some Perverted Battle Lines' from 'The Irish Worker' in which he express his disillusion at how the ruling classes in the countries of the Triple Alliance have appropriated "every phrase and rallying cry that their political opponents have coined against them", 1914 Sept. 26.
Typescript copy of article by James Connolly entitled 'Redmond Cannot Deilver the Goods' from 'The Irish Workers', 1914 Oct. 3.
Typescript copy of article by James Connolly entitled 'A Forward Policy for Volunteers' from 'The Irish Worker' in which he outlines his proposal for a "Forward" policy in relation the Irish Volunteers, 1914 Oct. 10.
Typescript copy of article by James Connolly entitled 'How England Sacrificed Belgium' from 'The Irish Worker' commenting on England's admirable fight for the neutrality of Belgium, 1914 Oct. 17.
Typescript copy of article by James Connolly entitled 'The Ballot of the Barricades' from 'The Irish Worker', 1914 Oct. 24.
Typescript copy of article by [James Connolly?] entitled 'What Africanders Owe the Empire' which focuses on the Boer's relationship with the British Empire, 1914 Nov. 7.
Typescript copy of article by James Connolly entitled 'Rally for Labour' from 'The Irish Worker' in which he muses on the state of things for the ordinary worker now that the initial fever of the war is practically over and how the rich are taking advantage of the situation to increase their profits, 1914 Nov. 14.
Typescript copy of article by James Connolly entitled 'The Hope of Ireland' from 'The Irish Worker' in which states the view that the working class are still "the anchor and foundation of any real nationalism that this country can show", 1914 Oct. 31.
Typescript copy of article by [James Connolly?] entitled 'Courtsmartial and Revolution' which discusses the British goverment's proposal to bring in legislation called the "Defence of the Realm Consolidation Act", 1914 Dec. 19.
Typescript copy of article by [James Connolly?] entitled 'Casualties' in which talks about the war and 1913 Lockout, 1915 Jan. 2.
Typescript copy of article by James Connolly entitled 'Can Warfare Be Civilised' in which he holds that "war is a relic of barbarism only possible because we are governed by a ruling class with barbaric ideas", 1915 Jan. 30.

Letter from Percy Friedberg to James Connolly in which he encloses payment relating to the renewal of his subscription for a quarter for 'The 'Weekly People' and to notify him in future about it and also regarding 'The Workers' Republic', 1901 Jun. 17.
Letter from Percy Friedberg to James Connolly in which he encloses payment for subscription renewal of 'The Workers' Republic' and 'The Weekly People', 1901 Sept. 3.
Letter from Percy Friedberg to James Connolly saying that he "succeeded in inducing the Finsbury Park branch to take a dozen Workers' Republic per month", 1901 Oct. 21.
Letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly saying he was delighted to see "his staunch manifesto on that course of systematic treachery on the part of the S.L.P. which culminated in the Smillie outrage", 1901 11 Nov..
Letter from Percy Friedberg to James Connolly saying he was pleased with the November issue of 'The Workers' Republic' and believes it will help the "No Compromise" propaganda considerably, 1901 Dec. 16.
Letter from Percy Friedberg to James Connolly talking about the Dublin results and is uncertain as to whther they are good or bad, 1902 Jan. 24.
Letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly in which he encloses a donation of £1 "to help the Workers' Republic Fund" but is regretful that he cannot afford to give any more at the present, 1902 Mar. 4.
Letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly asking if his letter has arrived as he is anxious to know "whether some post office clerk or other minion of oppression is squandering my hard earned savings on Porter & Pigsfeet", 1902 Mar. 11.
Letter from John Carstairs Matheson to James Connolly saying that he has appended of a letter that was sent "as a general protest against the Unity fakes", 1902 Mar. 16.
Letter from John Carstairs Matheson to unidentified recipient saying that he will try and get hold of a copy of the Finsbury Park Branch statement for him and has written to Percy Friedberg "asking him to send one or two", 1902 Sept. 9.
Letter from unidentified cousin to Lillie Connolly talking about her husbands imminent trip to America to get work and hopes that he gets something close to Troy where her cousin lives, undated.
Letter from K.M. Shannon to Lillie Connolly relating to James Connolly incarceration in Mountjoy Prison and plans to protest outside the prison to secure his release, 1913 Sept. 11.
Copies of statement by Nora Connolly regarding the final meeting with her father before his execution signed by herself and her mother Lillie Connolly, 1916.
Letter from Nora Connolly to Thomas Foran of the I.T.G.W.U. in which she presents her objection to the proposal regarding the offer of financial assistance from the union to the Connolly family, 1920 Aug. 20.
Letter from Lillie Connolly to Thomas Foran saying that she cannot accept the bounty and "would be acting contrary to his wishes" of her husband after being by her daughter Nora of the I.T.G.W.U.'s intentions, 1920 Aug. 10.

List of branches that have been formed since June 30th 1918 and gives the number as 122 up to the time of writing, 1918.
List of branches from which no census returns have been received and ones that have subsequently been completed are crossed out, 1918.
List giving an estimate of all the I.T.G.W.U. members working in employment under the banner of transport such as those working in the docks, railway, canals, carters, trams and others, 1918.
List giving an estimate of all the I.T.G.W.U. members working in employment under the banner of food and fuel such as those working in agriculture, creameries, butchers, breweries, turf and coal and other related sectors, 1918.
List giving an estimate of all the I.T.G.W.U. members working in employment under the banner of food and fuel such as those working in building, brickyards, textiles, laundries, tradesmen and other related sectors, 1918.
List giving an estimate of all the I.T.G.W.U. members working in employment under the banner of miscellaneous such as those working clerks, shop assistants, agents, theatres and public bodies, 1918.
Letter from Maurice Neligan, secretary of the Listowel, Co. Kerry branch of the I.T.G.W.U. addressed to J.J. Hughes, General Secretary of the I.T.G.W.U. in regard to officer appointments for the year of 1918, Jan. 9 1919.
'Irish Transport and General Workers' Union Annual Report for 1918'; Issued by authority of Executive Committee, 1918.
Census of membership forms for branches of the I.T.G.W.U. consisting of forms that were returned and completed starting with Arklow and ending with Youghal and are compiled in alphabetical order, 1918.
List of I.T.G.W.U. branches giving the numbers of their membership working in employment under the category of industries such as building, textile, munitions and other sectors, 1918.
List of I.T.G.W.U. branches giving the numbers of their membership working in employment under the category of industries such as agriculture, bakeries, hotel, fishing and other related sectors, 1918.
List of I.T.G.W.U. branches giving the numbers of their membership working in employment under the category of transport in the docks, on the canals, trains plus others, 1918.
List of I.T.G.W.U. branches giving the numbers of their membership working in employment under the category of miscellaneous in jobs such as clerks, shop assistants, agents, theatre and public bodies, 1918.
Notes by William O'Brien, and copy-letters from English trade union leaders, concerning the Irish anti-conscription campaign of 1918, 1918.
Notes by William O'Brien relating to the anti-conscription campaign of 1918 describing "our proposals", 1918.
Notes by William O'Brien relating to the anti-conscription campaign of 1918 in which he describes proposals set out in the Mansion House Conferenece that took place earlier in April of that year, 1918 24 Jun.
Notes by William O'Brien relating to the Mansion House Conference and discusses other meetings and upcoming events such as the 1918 Irish General Election, 1918 Nov. 20.
Copy-letters from English trade union leaders in relation to the anti-conscription campaign of 1918 addessed to the labour representatives whom attended the Mansion House Conference in 1918, 1918 May 6-8.
Letter from Caroline Margaret Douglas, Marchioness of Queensberry (better known by her pen name Sister Caroline) to the 'Workers' Republic' saying that she is "against the taking of life to gain anything on earth" as it is ultimately murder, undated.
Letter from Caroline Margaret Douglas, Marchioness of Queensberry (better known by her pen name Sister Caroline) to the 'Workers' Republic' thanking them for sending the papers to her and says she is too ill to write much and mentions the Boer War and its effect on the British Nation, undated.
Note from Caroline Margaret Douglas, Marchioness of Queensberry (better known by her pen name Sister Caroline) to the 'Workers' Republic' in which she argues that it is preferable to "hold for the truth without breaking the laws of a country", undated.
Letter from Caroline Margaret Douglas, Marchioness of Queensberry (better known by her pen name Sister Caroline) to the 'Workers' Republic' saying that she has not received her paper and hopes it has not failed again, undated.
Letter from Caroline Margaret Douglas, Marchioness of Queensberry (better known by her pen name Sister Caroline) to the 'Workers' Republic' in which she prays that god may "bless and guide for all and save you from breaking our father's law", undated.
Letter from Caroline Margaret Douglas, Marchioness of Queensberry (better known by her pen name Sister Caroline) to the 'Workers' Republic' in which she sympathises over their troubles and wonders why "someone who understands law is not appointed for papers such as yours" , 1900 Jun. 15.
Note from Caroline Margaret Douglas, Marchioness of Queensberry (better known by her pen name Sister Caroline) to the editor of the 'Workers' Republic' saying "they are all in the sight of the all just God murderers", 1900 Jun. 9.
Letter from Caroline Margaret Douglas, Marchioness of Queensberry (better known by her pen name Sister Caroline) to the 'Workers' Republic' saying that she has "nothing to do with anarchy or disorder of any kind", 1901 Oct. 25.
Postcard from the 'Daily People' to the 'Workers' Republic' asking them to send on the peridiocal to Patrick Costello of Ambler, Pennsylvania for one year, 1902.
Postcard from [Charles Spark?] asking the 'Irish Workers' Republic' to note his change of address and in an additional note that he has "received former issues o.k. but one", 1903 Mar. 2.
Postcard from the 'Daily People' to the 'Workers' Republic' asking them to be charged with 50 cent for 1 year's subscription to the periodical from J.U. Billings of Grand Junction, [Colorado?], U.S.A., 1903 Mar. 7.
Circular containing contents of lecture entitled "Labour in South India" by Dr. Gilbert Slater alluding to the geographical conditions, the social structure, the Indian government and other factors, 1924 Aug. 25.
Circular containing contents of lecture entitled 'The Scottish Trade Union Movement' delivered by William Elger, Gen. Sec. of the Scottish Trade Union Congress, giving a list of 10 items such as population, general history, development of trade unionism in 19th century, 1924 Aug. 25.
Circular containing contents of lecture entitled 'The Trade Union Movement in Czechoslovakia' delivered by Jaroslav Koudelka with four subject headings including the introduction, the new state, socialism and trade unionism, 1924 Aug. 26.
Circular showing the contents of a lecture entitled 'The Labour Movement' given by Thomas Johnson with subject headings such as trade union development, effect of world war amongst others, 1924 Aug. 24.
Circular containing contents of lecture entitled 'The British Trade Union Movement and Political Activity' by Rennie Smith including subjects such as the state until 1832 and the struggle for political reform, 1924 Aug. 27.
Circular containing contents of lecture entitled 'The British Trade Union Movement and Education' by Rennie Smith exploring such topics as the development of the ducational system for children and the present position of the elementary schools as well as others, 1924 Aug. 27.
Circular showing the contents of a lecture given by Maria Hodann entitled 'The German Youth Movement' looking at its significance and the causes of its development amongst other things, 1924 Aug. 28.
Circular showing the contents of a lecture by Rennie Smith entitled 'The I.F.T.U. : Education and the future' looking at the survey of studies undertaken and the rise of international workers' education amongst other things, 1924 Aug. 29.
Program of lectures for the second week held by the I.F.T.U. at the summer school at Oxford that took place between August 25th to 30th, 1924, 1924 Aug. 30.
Letter from Thomas Johnson to unidentified author saying that he has finally written to the chairman and formally tendered his resignation so that his action may be discussed in the Dáil, 1925 Jul. 16.
Letter from Thomas Johnson to [William O'Brien?] relating to his resignation from the office of secretary, 1925 Jul. 5.
Notice by Thomas Johnson writing to members of the National Executive of the Labour Party regarding his intention to step down as leader of the party but has decided to retain his seat as deputy, 1925 Jul. 5.
Letter from unidentified author to Thomas Johnson filling him in about the coal, the Metropole Picture House and the Shannon Scheme disputes, 1925 Oct. 2.
Newscuttings from the 'Irish Times' and the 'Irish Man' and includes an artiicle on Thomas Johnson and his career, 1927 Aug. - 1 Apr. 1960
Documents and newspaper cuttings pertaining to Labour Day, including the minutes of the Labour Day Committee in Dublin (1909), 1908-1915.
Notice to the trade and labour organisations of the city and and county of Dublin regarding the Labour Day demonstration taking place in May 1908, 1908 Mar. 20.
Notice entitled 'Labour Day Demonstration 1909' and outlines the resolutions and changes that the organisers would like to see be put into effect, 1909.
Notice from the Dublin United Trades Council and Labour League informing the officers and members of the date of the annual celebration of Labour day, 1911 Apr.
Notice entitled 'Labour Day Demonstration, 1911. Resolutions' in which all the improvements sought by the organisers are laid out with seven in total, 1911.
Notice entitled 'Labour Day Demonstration, 1913' for the workers and one of the resolutions outlined seeks to "affirm the right of every human being to work and live", 1913.
Notice entitled 'Labour Day Demonstration, 31st May, 1914' from the Dublin Trades and Labour Council informing their officers and members of the date and location of this year's celebration, 1914 May 31.
Notice entitled 'Labour Day, Demonstration, 1914' setting out the resolutions and "extends fraternal greetings to the workers of every country who are striving for the emancipation of their class", 1914.
Notice entitled 'Labour Day Demonstration, 30th May, 1915' and advises due to the uncertainty of all that is going on that efforts should be made to consolidate forces in order to defend any attacks made on their respective organisations, 1915 May 30.
Newcuttings relating to Labour Day from the 'Evening Telegraph' and other newspaper publication reporting on the various demonstrations held over a period of time, 1908-1915.
Notes by William O'Brien on the formation and establishment of the Irish Socialist Republican Party and of movements which preceded it including a list of members featuring Padraic Pearse, Eamon de Valera amongst others, 1896-1904.
Letter from Seán T. O Ceallaigh to [James Connolly?] of the Irish Neutrality League asking him to attend a meeting of his committee, [1914?].
Circular inviting interested parties to attend a conference in Groome's Hotel in Cavendish in order to discuss starting an Anti-Conscription movement, [1914?].
Circular by James Connolly inviting individuals to attend a meeting in order to discuss the war and the subject of neutrality, [1914?].
Circular by Sean T. O'Ceallaigh and Seán Miloy calling for the need for an association to be formed with the imminent threat of conscription for the young men of Ireland on the horizon, [?1914].
Note from James Connolly to William O'Brien written on draft circular calling the conference which established the Irish Neutrality League, 1914 Sept.
Circular from the Irish Neutrality League inviting the citizenry to attend the opening public meeting of the Irish Neutrality League, 1914 Oct. 5.
Circular extending an invite to a conference so as discuss the different ways in which to prevent the enactment of conscription in Ireland and also advises that the country organises and mobilises itself against this threat, 1915 June 5.
Notice from Micheal O'Foghludha inviting those to attend a meeting in accordance with the decision arrived at the Conscription Conference held the previous Tuesday, 1915 Jun. 12.
Letter from Sean T. O Ceallaigh to William O'Brien inviting him to attend a meeting in order "to form a committee to organise a public meeting of protest against imprisonment of Irish Volunteers", 1915 Aug. 23.
Letter from Seán P. Campbell to William O'Brien informing him of the date and time for the weekly meeting of the anti-conscription committee, 1915 Oct. 10.
Letter from unidentified author to William O'Brien informing him that J. White has been updated as to the position held in affairs of this kind as well as the procedure to be adopted for reinstatement in his particular branch of your union, undated.
Letter from [T. Ó Concúbar?], of the Agricultural Department in Dáil Eireann, to William O'Brien informing him that has got in touch with the Labour Department and gave him a mandate to go to Wexford to look at the disputes between the I.T.G.W.U. Farmer's Union and also with the other agricultural labour people, 1920 Oct. 21.
Letter from [T. Ó Concúbar?], of the Agricultural Department in Dáil Eireann, to William O'Brien saying that he has made arrangements to go to Kildavin on Wednesday next and and will do his best in the matter, 1920 Nov. 8.
Letter from unidentified author to William O'Brien asking him to send another copy of his letter regarding Arigna Mines as it seems to have been mislaid, 1921 May 23.
Letter from Department of Trade and Commerce to William O'Brien regarding an order prohibiting the importation of English saddlery and harness, 1921 Sept. 12.
Document issued by the Department of Economic Affairs in the event of the matter of a dispute between the Great Southern and Eastern Railway Company and their employees, 1921 Sept. 30.
Note from Óglaigh na h-Éireann to William O'Brien asking him to deal with a case of someone who is having difficulties joining the I.T.G.W.U., 1921 Sept. 31.
Letter from W.T. Cosgrave, Minister for Local Government, to William O'Brien telling him that he has forwarded a copy of his letter to the Minister for Agriculture, 1921 Oct. 21.
Envelope with a summons enclosed for William O'Brien from Dáil Éireann to attend a Republican Court, 1921 Oct. 15.
Letter from [Richard Mulcahy?] to William O'Brien wishing to inform him that "Messrs. Ross & Co. have agrreed that the dispute between them and your union should be settled by arbitration", 1921 Oct. 28.
Letter from [William O'Brien?] to the O.C., Dublin Brigade of the I.R.A. concerning an application to the Fish and Poultry Section of the [I.T.G.W.U.?] and makes clear that the executive of the union does not intend to interfere with the decision of the branch, 1921 Nov. 1.
Letter from the Chief of Police to William O'Brien informing him that resources are limited and honouring such a request is not an option at this time, 1921 Dec. 19.
Memorandum from T.D. Hallinan to Richard Mulcahy, Minister of Defence, thanking him for the "protection afforded us during the recent labour trouble here", 1922 Feb. 24.
Letter from Michael Collins to William O'Brien inviting him to attend the first meeting of the newly-elected parliament to be held at the Theatre of the Royal Dublin Society, 1922 Jun. 28.
Letter from the Department of Defence to William O'Brien acknowledging receipt of the communication regarding the arrest of Messrs. Jennings, Loydon and O'Dowd at Ballinrobe , 1922 Aug. 10.
Charge sheet for Kitty Costello and includes being in possession of documents without the proper authority and several issues of 'Poblacht na h-Éireann' both deemed to be in breach of the security of the state, 1923 Apr. 11.
Document entitled 'The Constitution' pertaining to the draft constitutiion of the Irish Free State and asks whether the treaty can be amended for the benefit of Ireland, [1922].
Copy of document entitled 'Memorandum of Executive' containing the first section of the draft constitution of the Irish Free State, 1922.
Copy of document entitled 'Motion by Deputy Thrift in Committee Re: Articles 50 to 59" and also containing subsections relating to amendments to the constitution, [1922].
Notice from Henry Harrison to William O'Brien containing "certain amendments to the draft constitution of the Irish Free State" of which he considers necessary, 1922 Sept. 18.
Copy of address made by Kevin O'Higgins to Thomas Johnson in response to a question posed by the Labour Party to which he will attempt to give a more definitive answer than previously, 1922 Sept. 22.
Copy of statement issued by the IRA addressed to each TD regarding their opposition to the treaty and bringing an end to the Civil War as quickly as possible, 1922.
Letter from the IRA to William O'Brien, secretary of the Irish Labour Party, issuing a warning about possible action against railways under Free State control, 1922 Aug. 3.
Note from the IRA to William O'Brien telling him that the enclosed is for his immediate consideration, 1922 Sept. 8.
Letter from Ernie O'Malley, Commandant O/C Northern and Eastern Command of the IRA, in which he encloses 15 authenticated statements setting out particulars of the treatment meted out to Republican prisoners carried out by the Provisional Government, 1922 Sept. 25.
Auditor's report on an examination of the Workers Union of Ireland's annual returns. It also contains miscellaneous documents authored by W.H. Engledow, 1870-1939.
Letter from W.H. Engledow to unidentified recipient concerning his efforts to ascertain the identity of the member of the Domville family "who syns or rather officially counter-syns the foot" of an unidentified document, 1870 Nov. 28.
Transcript of document by W.H. Engledow of unidentified author describing various paintings set in Rome and Venice amongst other locations, undated.
Newspaper cuttings regarding the Gaelic League, the Irish language revival, Irish poetry, and the Home Rule BIll in the Irish language, 1947-1894 and undated.
Postcard from E[oghan] O'Gramhna (Eugene O'Growney) to Daniel O'Brien thanking him for the £0-10-0 he left him and requesting he inform him when he receives the correct magazine, 1890 Aug. 14.
Note from Sean Plémion (John Fleming), editor of the Gaelic Journal, to [Daniel O'Brien] requesting whether he would prefer to be sent some additional numbers of "G.J." [Gaelic Journal] or would he prefer to send them onto Dollards for binding, 1890 May 12.
Postcard from E[oghan] O'Gramhna (Eugene O'Growney) to Daniel O'Brien informing him the Gaelic Union acknowledge the £0-10-0 they recevied from him and also requesting on behalf of the Union, that he write to them, in Irish, if he has anything to say, 1891 Jan. 04.
Postcard from E[oghan] O'Gramhna (Eugene O'Growney) to Daniel O'Brien informing him he received his freindly letter cotnaining £0-10-0 and also that "An Spailpín Fánach" will be in print soon, 1892 Oct. 07.
Copy of extracts from the diary of Daniel O'Brien concerning the death of both John F. Meagher and John Fleming and also regarding attending meetings of the Gaelic League, 1893 Sep. 26-1896 Jun. 12.
Membership card of the Gaelic League belonging to Daniel O'Brien for the years 1893-1894, 1893-1894.
Letter from John [Eoin] Mac Neill to Laurence Keily thanking him for his and Mr [Daniel] O'Brien's £0-5-0 subscriptions to The Gaelic League and informing him he will have great pleasure in proposing their names for membership if they are not already members, 1894 Mar. 17.
Acknowledgement from the Gaelic League, signed by Seosamh Laoide, to Daniel O'Brien for the payment of a half crown for his membership fee until the end of the seventh month of 1894, 1894 Mar. 20.
Note from the Gaelic League, from the treasurers Seosamh Laoide and Seaghan Ua hÓgáin, informing [Daniel O'Brien] they have great respect towards him for his help regarding the Irish language, 1894 Mar. 22.
Letter from John [Eoin] Mac Neill to Laurence Keily informing him that due to the great pressures of business and prepapring for the Irish Language Congress he forgot to send his reply letter which he states is enclosed, along with membership cards for himself and Mr [Daniel] O'Brien, 1894 Apr. 18.
Diary entry written by [Daniel O'Brien?] regarding Jeremiah O'Donovan Rossa's visit to Carrick to give his lecture "on his prison life" and also regarding the death of William Joseph O'Neill Daunt, 1894 Jun. 29.
Letter from John Hogan [Séan Ó hÓgáin] and J. H. Lloyd [Seosamh Laoide], treasurers of the Gaelic League, to Daniel O'Brien informing him his subscription for the current year of 1898 is due, 1895 Feb. 23.
Acknowledgement from the Gaelic League, signed by Seaghán Ua hÓgáin, treasurer, to Domhnall Ua Briain [Daniel O'Brien] for the payment of £0-2-6 for his membership fee until the seventh month of 1895, 1895 Mar. 19.
Postcard from Pádraig Ó Laoghaire to Daniel O'Brien informing him his stories on Munster will be printed in Irish and also that he has has nothing to be worried or afraid about, 1895 Apr. 23.
