Postcard from Pádraig Ó Laoghaire to Daniel O'Brien thanking him for his letter and the money enclosed and also informing him that he will send on the book as soon as it is ready, 1895 Jun.18.
Acknowledgement from the Gaelic League, signed by Seosamh Laoide, treasurer, to Daniel O'Brien for the payment of £0-5-0 for his memebership for seven months, 1896.
Notes written by unknown author on the death of John E. Walsh, a cousin of Daniel O'Brien's, and also on Daniel O'Briens joining of the R.I.C in 1858, undated
Note written by unknown author mentioning names and events such as the Gaelic Journal Vo.1 No.12 and also informing that Daniel O'Brien was a sergeant when he married in 1875, undated.
Letter from [Ed?] Redmond to Head Constable [Daniel] O'Brien thanking him for the Gaelic Journal, speaking of the severe critic and corrections of a story and stating he has added in his own corrections, undated.
Notes written by unknown author on the history of the O'Brien family in the Parish of Ardfinar, the evictions by the Earl of Glengall in Co. Tipperary, and also referencing works including speeches of Daniel O'Connell and the history of the famine, undated.
Gaelic League booklet providing information on the Irish language, its present condition and its prospects, in both Irish and English, undated.
Booklet providing information on Gaelic books avaliable to be gotten from Patrick O'Brien, 46 Cuffe Street, Dublin, including their titles and price, undated.
Envelope containing notes on its contents which include the membership card of Daniel O'Brien, leaflets issued by the Gaelic League, letters, notes and cards from various authors and also extracts from Daniel O'Brien's diary, undated.
Typescript letter from P. J. O' Brien to William O'Brien regarding articles written on him in the 'Nenagh Guardian' and 'Unity' and also problems that have arose with elections in Counties Westmeath and Meath, 1943 Jan. 07.
Typescript letter from P. J. O'Brien to William O'Brien regarding articles in the 'Union', 'New Leader' and 'Nenagh Guardian' and also referring to "A.C.'s" reply letter concerning the termination of the services of "Pollock" , 1944 Jan. 22.
Typescript letter from P. J. O'Brien to Alfred O'Rahilly, President of U.C.C, requesting permission to re-publish his article "A Showdown is Overdue" which appeared in 'The Standard', and includes Alfred O'Rahilly's response stating he can republish the article but advises him to wait and see another article or his response article to criticisms he has received, 1944 Feb. 12-Feb. 14.
Letter from Alfred O'Rahilly to P. J. O'Brien regarding the split in the Labour Party, how the statement written on it in a newspaper was essentially taken up with information on the row between the ITGWU and [James] Larkin, and also asking questions on the information that was provided about the Labour Party, 1944 Feb. 14.
Typescript letter from P. J. O'Brien to Wiliam O'Brien regarding the approval and opposition towards the Labour Party's action and also informing him they have asked their branches to reaffirm their allegiance to "A.C.L.P.", 1944 Feb. 16.
Typescript letter from P. J. O'Brien to [William O'Brien] informing him Alfred O'Rahilly is prepared to provide assistance in the preparation of the Labour Party and in the drafting of their Constitution, and also recommending him highly for the position, 1944 Feb. 21.
Typescript letter from P. J. O'Brien to unknown recipient informing them of an Administrative Council meeting of the Labour Party and also that the Carrigaline Branch of the Labour Party has decided to transfer to the National Labour Party, 1944 Feb. 23.
Typescript letter from S. [Ua Clárbán?] to William O'Brien informing him of an attached letter from SD. P. Bergin and stating that said letter does not accurately describe the correct decision of the Party or the facts of the Labour Party meeting in Carlow, and also including copy of said letter, 1944 Feb. 21-23.
Notes written by [Alfred O'Rahilly] to [P. J. O'Brien] regarding establishing a pamphlet for the I.T.G.W.U. which would describe the reasons behind not wanting James Larkin in the Union and to develop and describe the reforms they want to make, undated.
Letter from Percy Friedberg to [William O'Brien?] informing him "the great Irish leader" John Redmond spoke at a big meeting for in Bermondsey to an audience of workmen regarding buying out landlords, 1902 Dec. 13
Letter from A. Montgomery to William O'Brien thanking him for sending on pamphlets regarding his Party and providing an address of a person he believes may be interested in receiving a pamphlet, 1905 Jul. 27.
Copy of typescript letter from John K. Ingram to William O'Brien informing him he has directed his bookseller to send him a copy of his book 'History of Political Economy' and also describing his views as a "positivist", 1905.
Letter from Sidney Webb to William O'Brien informing him he cannot afford to buy the books he has written in order to present them to the library of The Socialist Party and expressing his displeasure that O'Brien has not exhausted the means at his disposal for obtaining a loan of the books, 1905 Nov. 22.
Letter from Adolphus William Shields to [William O'Brien] informing him he has not had time to write a new paper over the holidays and will now have to dress up and re-use an older paper entitled 'Signs of the Times', 1906 Jan. 05.
Letter from William G. Orr to William O'Brien discussing the reasoning behind the unlikelihood of setting up a Socialist Labour Party in Belfast, of how the Belfast Socialist Society is for all intents and purposes an S.L.P. branch, mentioning leaving the party and establishing his own party and also his uncertainty at joining O'Brien's Party, 1907 Nov. 06.
Postcard from [J.S.S.?] to Willaim O'Brien asking whether he would like to organise a postcard campaign, using a similar image to the one on the postcard, for Dublin against "lanlordism", 1909 Oct. 20.
Circular invitation from J. W. O'Beirne to William O'Brien for his attendance at an informal meeting in order to make preliminary arrangements for the celebration of the birth of "one of Ireland's greatest social and political thinkers", James Fintan Lalor, 1909 Dec. 12.
Postcard from P. J. Hoey to William O'Brien of a picture of the demonstration against the execution of Francisco Ferrer by the Spanish Governement, 1910 Sep. 23.
Letter from Seaghan de Brúin to [William O'Brien] informing him of his resignation from the post as secretary of the Dublin branch of the Independent Labor Party of Ireland and providing his reasons for resigning, 1912 Aug. 28.
Telegram from William Patrick Partridge to William O'Brien stating "greetings from scene of martyrs effort and death, success to meeting and freedom to Connolly, keep the old fly flying", 1913 Sept. 14.
Copy of letter from a despondent James Connolly, in Mountjoy Prison, to William O'Brien requesting he send in papers to him as he has asked many of his visitors to do so and he has only received three papers to date, 1913 Sep.
Postcard from [Tom?] to William O'Brien informing him he did not receive his letter in time to complete his writing in order to speak, 1913 Sep. 30.
Postcard from [Tom] to William O'Brien informing of the meetings he is holding in Bristol and Aronmouth and the amount he has collected, 1913 Oct. 13.
Letter from Conal O'Riordan to William O'Brien informing him to send all correspondence to his home address rather than to the Independent Magazine and informing him he will not be bringing "them" before the committee but he can't promise the Indepedent magazine won't, 1913 Nov. 05.
Letter from Conal O'Riordan to William O'Brien informing him the Lord Mayor heard from Mr Coghlan, the secretary of the Employess Exectutives and describing what was said regarding his committee meeting with Mr Bowerman, Mr. Gosling and Mr. Seldon in order to discuss the "hypothetical case" [Peace Conference between O'Brien and the employees] that was put forward in their previous correspondence , 1913 Nov. 08.
Letter from Conal O'Riordan to William O'Brien regarding an enclosed formal letter that he hope will be as much use as possible and also informing him he has been in touch with Mr [James] Connolly, 1913 Nov. 09.
Letter from Conal O'Riordan to William O'Brien regarding having not replied due to having not received a definitive answer to the proposition of a Peace Conference, requesting the final report of the Industrial Peace Committee, who at that time ceased to exist and informing him he has been called away to London, 1913 Nov. 12.
Copy of extract from a manifesto printed in the 'Irish Worker' entitled "Irish Trade Unions Congress & Labour Party National Executive" which speaks of the Irish nation's right of enacting National Legislation, 1914 Aug. 08.
Postcard from William O'Brien to Thomas McPartlin requesting he give a letter that may arrive at his home to [James] Connolly if he is in Dublin for the anti-war meeting and also asking him to have a talk with Connolly about the American trip, 1914 Aug. 08.
Postcard from William O'Brien to Thomas McPartlin regarding the date of the Socialist Labour Party's anti-war meeting, reminding him to discuss the American tour with Connolly and also discussing having information wired to him due to troubles, 1914 Aug. 15.
Copy of letter from James Connolly to William O'Brien regarding having received and made alterations to a "copy" and referring to [John] Redmond's speech as a "desperate situation", 1914 Sep. 23.
Circular from the Independent Labour Party of Ireland entitled 'Appeal to the Irish Working Class', circa 1914 Oct.
Typescript letter from P. T. Daly to William O'Brien informing him of an upcoming meeting for the Irish Trade Union Congress and Labour Party to be held at the Library, Trades Hall, Capel Street, Dublin, to discuss arrangements for the forthcoming congress, 1915 Feb. 27.
Letter from Helena Molony to William O'Brien requesting if he could speak alongside Miss Duggan and Madame Markievicz at the Reform League meeting and also orgainsing a meeting of their share holders to elect a committee, 1915 Nov. 02.
Letter from E. Mallon to Mary Frances O'Brien informing her that William O'Brien has been moved from the Knutsford Prison to Frongoch Prison in North Wales, discussing ways of sending parcels to him and also assuring her she will ask about him when she visits next, 1916 Jun. 27.
Envelope address to William O'Brien, originally as an Irish prisoner of war in Reading and subsequently altered to 43 Belvidere Road, Dublin, 1916 Aug. 02.
Typescript note written by William O'Brien to the Right Honourable Herbert Samuel, M. P., Home Secretary, applying for permits for himself and Thomas Foran to visit Trade Union officials who are interned in England, 1916 Nov. 08.
Copy letter from Jane Carstairs Matheson on behalf of her husband John Carstairs Matheson to William O'Brien regarding letters he received from James Connolly which O'Brien would like to use in Connolly's biography, 1916 Nov. 11.
Typescript letter from Michael Collins, secretary of the Irish National Aid and Volunteer Dependents' Fund, to [William O'Brien] informing him of a special meeting of the Executive at the request of Mr. Michael Corrigan, solicitor, regarding the "Longford Leader" case, 1917 Jun. 07.
Partial letter from unknown author to William O'Brien regarding his Party visiting Dublin, Alter's efforts of late and him bringing the question to Council, applying for permits to travel and also Alexander Kerensky's proposal that all big belligerents should raise money jointly in order to indemify all the small nations who suffered as a result of the war, 1917 Jul. 13.
Tyepscript letter from Richard Mulcahy, Honourary secretary of the Wolfe Tone Memorial Association, to William O'Brien informing him the Wolfe Tone Memorial Committee requests his co-operation in the arrangements of the funeral of Thomas Ashe and notifying him of the meeting details, 1917 Sep. 26.
Letter from Vincent C. Ellis to William O'Brien thanking him for his and his Party's support during the elections which secured him a vacancy in Portrane, 1917 Jul. 27.
Typescript letter from Michael Collins, secretary of the Irish National Aid and Volunteer Dependants' Fund, to Thomas Foran informing him of an enclosed schedule containing his statement of losses made to the committee, 1917 Aug. 09.
Telegraph from unknown author to William O'Brien sending their best wishes for the Mansion House Conference where he represented the Labour Party and the Irish transport and general workers' union in talks dealing with resisting the conscription of the Irish nation into World War One and also writes "that the struggle for human freedom and the fraternity of nations will be brought to a speedy and triumphant conclusion", 1918 Feb. 04.
Typescript letter from Michael Collins, secretary of the Irish National Aid and Volunteer Dependents' Fund, to William O'Brien requesting his attendence at an American Grants Committee meeting in Mr. D. O'Connor's office, solicitor, 13 Westmoreland Street, 1918 Feb. 06.
Copy of letter from Jim Connell to William O'Brien thanking him for sending on articles relating to the Mansion House Conference and informing him of a lecture he did the previous night to the Dulwich Branch of the Irish Labour Party, 1918 Feb. 25.
Typescript letter from unknown author from the Irish National Aid and Volunteer Dependents' Fund to Mary Frances O'Brien questioning whether McGinley's case should be brought before the committee due to the injuries he sustained during the Rising and also hoping her brother, William OBrien, will attend the meeting, f 1918 Mar. 20.
Typescript letter from Michael Collins, secretary of the Irish National Aid and Volunteer Dependents' Fund, to William O'Brien requesting his attendance at a meeting for the American Grants Committee at Mr. D. O'Connor's office, solicitor, 1918 Mar. 26.
Letter from [M. Timber?] to William O'Brien thanking him for extracting his verse from the "Voice [of Labour?]", discussing the printing of his book and his other poetry, and also mentioning the publication of Peadar Kearney's poems and his National Anthem, 1918 Apr. 23.
Typescript letter from Eamonn MacAlpine to P. T. Daly and William O'Brien regarding them contesting parliamentary seats for Dublin and suggesting putting James Larkin's names before the electors for the Harbour Division and also informing them he has enclosed a copy of a resolution they passed, 1918 May 10.
Letter from of Camille Huysmans of the British section of the International Socialist Bureau to William O'Brien informing him he would be happy to meet his Executive and accept his invitation to the congress but would not be able to get the authorisation, 1918 Jul. 30.
Letter from William McGinley to [William O'Brien] congratulating him on his election as Secretary of the Irish Trade Union Congress and also mentions his displeasure at [P.T.] Daly's election on the Executive, 1918 Aug. 13.
Letter from Liam Ó Rinn to [William O'Brien] regarding his health issues and mentioning how Labour affairs and Gaelic affairs are on his mind continuously, 1918 Aug. 19.
Letter from Kitty O'Connor, Honourary Secretary of the [National Aid Association], to William O'Brien requesting him to attend a meeting the following day, 1918 Aug. 19.
Letter from William McGinley to William O'Brien discussing O'Briens latest triumphs in the political domain, recent political news in Ireland, his time in prison and also Mrs. Tom Clarke's ill health, 1918 Aug. 24.
Letter from William J. Walsh, Archbishop of Dublin, to William O'Brien regarding a project O'Brien referred to in a previous letter and informing him he cannot do anything practical with it until he hears from the nuns, 1918 Sep. 16.
Letter from J. King, from the House of Commons, to William O'Brien informing him his wire went through to him that morning and mentioning: "I asked this question yesterday", 1918 Nov. 21.
Copy and partial copy of letter from Seán T. Ó Ceallaigh to William O'Brien introducing him Mr. Frank P. Walsh of New York, Chairman of the American Commission on Irish Independence, requesting O'Brien organise for him to meet all prominent labour workers during his time in Ireland and also informing him he has become well-acquainted with his brother Thomas John O'Brien, 1919 May 01-1944 Mar. 25.
Postcard from [P.] to William O'Brien informing him he is delighted with his time in Kerry, 1919 Jun. 06.
Typescript letter from William O'Brien to P. O'Toole of the Carlow ITGWU requesting his views on actions that can aid farm labourers and also what farms near Carlow town he would like to select to help, 1919 Jul. 02.
Letter from Ramsay MacDonald to William O'Brien regarding a complaint he has received in which O'Brien said that he mentioned a deputation he received from Ireland on Home Rule and the general situation in Ireland appealed to the Labour Party in Great Britain not to drop conscription as that would play into the hands of the Sinn Féin Party and asking whether it is true that he is saying this, 1919 Aug. 31.
Letter from Tadhg Barry to William O'Brien requesting his advice for the upcoming elections as he believes they will be rather complicated in Cork and informing him he will be running for the Labour Party in the elections, 1919 Nov. 10.
Letter from Tadhg Barry to William O'Brien informing him of his displeasure that O'Brien did not recognise their last letter as personal and notifying him that he must now attend a meeting where the remainder of the party will be told of Barry's interference, 1919 Nov. 12.
Typescript letter from Alice Stopford Green to Mr. Figgis [Hodges & Figgis] thanking him for his Christmas card of appreciation and sympathy, 1919 Dec. 27.
Letter from Sean O'Mahony to [William O'Brien] congratulating him on the recent elections, complimenting his work on the 'Independent' and speaking of his time in Mountjoy Prison, 1919 Feb. 04.
Typescript letter from Gilbert Lynch to William O'Brien informing him of the success of his candidature thus far and also that he has informed correspondents to send post to him in the prison, 1920 Mar. 19.
Letter from J. H. MacDonnell, Solicitor, to William O'Brien informing him of his postition as a prisoner in England, whereby he may move around in Great Britain but will be arrested at once if he returns to Ireland, 1920 Apr. 27.
Typescript letter from [General Sir Nevil] Macready to [Thomas Foran] requesting a meeting in order for him to "get a grip of the conditions in this country", 1920 May 04.
Copy letter of reply from Thomas Foran to General Sir Nevil Macready informing him William O'Brien would be the best person to speak to in relation to the Irish Labour movement, and notifying him O'Brien is at present unavailable due to his internment in Britain, 1920 May 04.
Copy letter from Camille Huysmans to [William O'Brien] requesting reports and providing the headings which are needed for the discussions of these problems at the Congress of Geneva, 1920 May 06.
Letter from [Mim?] to William O'Brien thanking him for his letter from London and describing her holiday in Omeath, Co. Louth, 1920 Jul. 31.
Letter from E. Lynch to William O'Brien informing him he would be pleased if he could inform his and [Jack?] Dowling's relatives they are detained and also requesting a suitcase, newspapers and medicine, 1920 Dec. 22.
Postcard from P. K. Hawthorne to William O'Brien sending his sincerest greetings to all, 1921 Jan. 13.
Letter from Laurence O'Neill, Lord Mayor of Dublin, to William O'Brien informing him of the date and time of the Irish White Cross meeting, 1921 Jan. 23.
Letter and copy letters from Seán T. Ó Ceallaigh to William O'Brien requesting literature on James Connolly, James Larkin and the Labour moverment of Ireland for a friend in France and also that he will pay him back when her can, 1921 Feb. 19.
Typescript letter from Éamonn De Valera to William O'Brien requesting O'Brien to secure an agreement between both parties of the Cemeteries' dispute in order for funeral arrangements to be facilitated by the members of the Unions involved for the funeral of Archbishop Walsh, 1921 Apr. 13.
Letter and copy of letter from Rev. Peter Coffey, Professor of Maynooth College, to William O'Brien thanking him for a copy of his booklet, discussing articles, including his own, that sympathise with the aspirations of Irish Labour and also writing in reference to "The Axe to the Roof", 1921 Apr. 23.
Letter from Cathleen O'Moore to William O'Brien informing him Mr [Patrick] O'Moore is very hopeful at regaining his position, acknowledging that prisoners do not usually receive allowoances after they are realeased and notifying him that they will repay the amount allowed to Mr. O'Moore since his release, 1912 May 23.
Copy letter from William O'Brien to Sir John Anderson informing him of a visit to his house by the Crown Forces, the damage they caused to his records which dealt with the Trade Union, Socialist, and Co-operative movements for the past 30 years, the removal of these records from his home and a reply letter on the behalf of Sir John Anderson notifying O'Brien that the case will be thoroughly investigated, 1921 May 24-25.
Postcard from "R." to William O'Brien thanking him for the enclosures he received, offering his condolences on all that he lost [records] and requesting he give him "the heads at once" regarding the next meeting, 1921 May 30.
Postcard from "R" to William O'Brien thanking him for notes he sent and informing him his work should be seen early, 1921 Jun. 02.
Copy letter from Michael Collins to William O'Brien forwarding on a mesage "from a very reliable source" of possible enemy spies attempting to gain access to meetings and any information on Irish Trade Unions, 1921 Jul. 06.
Typescript letter from William O'Brien to Éamon De Valera requesting if he would see Dr. Bhat, delegate of the Trade Union Congress of India, as he is very anxious to have the privilege of speaking with him, 1921 Aug. 04.
Reply letter from Éamon De Valera to William O'Brien informing him he received his letter and met with Dr. Bhat, 1921 Aug. 05.
Copy letter from M.J. O'Leary, assistant secretary of the Socialist Party of Ireland, to William O'Brien informing him of the resolution that was passed at their meeting to expel him and Comrade O'Shannon from the Party due to their guilt of breach of party discipline and their futile efforts to build up a Communist Party in Ireland, 1921 Oct. 18.
Telegraph from "McGrath" to William O'Brien informing him he will see him Saturday morning, 1921 Dec. 01.
Copy letters from John [Sean] McGrath to Thomas O'Reilly, cattle agent, informing him he is sending a wagon of excellent bullocks in order for him to get the best possible price for them, 1921.
Typescript letter from Joseph McGrath, Minister for Labour, to William O'Brien informing him he is taking note that he has secured the services of Mr. McMillan and will pass on his letter to Michael Collins, 1922 Feb. 01.
Copy letter from [William O'Brien?] to Seosamh MagCraith (Joseph McGrath) informing him Lord Justice O'Connor is agreeable to act as Chairman of the Railway Commission if appointed and also assuring him the question of time does not matter as O'Connor will give his full time to the work of the Commission, 1922 Mar. 03.
Copy letters from Seán T. O'Kelly and Henry Boland to Thomas Johnson, secretary of the Labour Party, and subsequently forwarded onto William O'Brien, thanking the Labour Party for their invitations to the recently elected Dáil members to a meeting at the Mansion House but informing them they cannot attend as they believe the conference can more efficiently persue their objectives uninfluenced by their presence, 1922 Jul. 19.
Copy letter from Peadar O'Donnell, I.R.A. Executive, to William O'Brien informing him that P[atrick] O'Brien has been paid off from work and requesting if William O'Brien can adjust matters in this case in order to help his family, 1922 Jul. 23.
Letter from Sean McGlynn to William O'Brien, T.D. for South Dublin, requesting to meet with him to discuss the circumstances of his arrest and details which lead to his arrest, 1922 Aug. 20.
Copy letter from W. T. Cosgrave to "Town Clerk" regarding the proposed plan of the extension of the housing area in Marino by 77 acres, 1922 Aug. 26.
Typescript letter from Seosamh MagCraith (Joseph McGrath) to William O'Brien regarding a letter sent to him by O'Brien, initially from R. Davys, and mentioning there is, after investigation, "very definite information regarding the activities of McCauley, 1922 Sep. 30.
Typescript letter from Hugh McCarth, secretary to the School Attendence Department of Dublin Corporation, to William O'Brien forwarding him a resolution passed unanimously at the South West Divisional School Attendence Committee meeting which was of congratulations to O'Brien on his election as T.D. , 1922 Oct. 10.
Typescript letter from Colm Ó Murchadha to William O'Brien forwarding on a resolution passed by Dáil Éireann in which it states a Committee on Procedure be appointed and requesting him to attend a meeting for the Committee on Procedure, 1922 Nov. 20.
Letter and copy letter from Sean T. O'Kelly to William O'Brien regarding his worries over the large number of "young lads" in the Gormanstown internment camp, the delayed pace at which post arrives and departs and the deliberate withholding of newspapers by the officers, 1922 Oct. 27.
Letter from K[athleen] Lynn to William O'Brien requesting his party put a question to the parliament at the next meeting in order to get Miss Annie MacSwiney off hunger strike as Lynn does not believe she has the resistance for it, 1923 Feb. 27.
Typescript copy letter from "Runai" (secretary) to Joseph McGrath, and subsequently forwarded onto William O'Brien by unknown author, regarding the large numbers of unemployed in Mallow, Co. Cork, the reasoning behind the unemployment, requesting the government contractor to use the local Labour Exchange for workers for rebuilding the Blackwater Viaduct and the strain this is putting on the Unemployment Fund, 1923 Feb. 24.
Letter from [P. Hogan?] to [William O'Brien] requesting details of the particulars for the post of Labour organiser and providing information of his past experiences, 1923 Mar. 13.
Copy letter from Kevin O'Higgins, Minister for Home Affairs, to William O'Brien of a transcript of a telephone conversation between J. J. Farrell of the Cinema Association to the Ministry detailing the picture houses in which the Transport Union have withdrawn staff from, 1923 Mar. 26.
Letter from Joe [Joseph McGrath?] to William O'Brien regarding the payment of £700 to the "co op" and mentioning arrangements made to pay on the "nail" their account in future, 1923 Mar. 26.
Copy letter from Kevin O'Higgins to William O'Brien informing him a joint deputation of representatives of Theatre and Cinema proprietors, operators and staff visited him with their views and also requesting to meet with O'Brien and other Labour Leaders urgently to discuss these matters, 1923 March.
Copy letters from M[argaret] Rodgers, aunt to Peadar O'Donnell, to William O'Brien informing him of urgent business relating to Peadar O'Donnell in which he has been transferred from the Curragh Camp to Finner Camp, Co. Donegal, as hostage and is to be shot if any activities take place in Donegal and requesting his and the Unions help in this matter, 1923 Apr. 07.
Copy letter from A.S. O'Muircadhaigh (Henry Murray) to William O'Brien on behalf of Joseph McGrath regarding the case of Charles O'Reilly and informing him "that there is no definite charge which can be preferred against this prisoner", 1923 May 29.
Copy of letter from Eamon O'Duibhir to [Thomas] Johnson proposing the Party invest in The Gael Co-Operative Society to an amount between £1,400 - £1,700 for machinery and informing him of the measures the company has taken to ensure its survival, 1923 Jul. 16.
Letter from [C. O'S?] to William O'Brien asking what the current situation is with defeated candidtates in the I.T. & G.W.U., infoming him he heard from "T. J." from Wales and advised him on the unofficial delegate conference and mentioning the rumour he heard of O'Brien resigning from the Union E.C., 1923 Sep. 16.
Letter from Eamon O'Duibhir to William O'Brien informing him of his failed business The Gael Co-Operative Society, detailing a new business idea in the milk industry and asking if he could be guarantor, with enclosed pamphlet of said idea and reply letter of rejection from O'Brien as he is at present working on a large overdraft himself, 1925 Mar. 20-25.
Letter from Thomas Brody to William O'Brien regarding having met once, his frienship with James Connolly when he was in the USA, collecting money for the "revolution" after the Easter Rising and also speaking of his displeasure of the Irish Civil War, [circa 1923 Jul. 21- 1925 Jul. 06].
Postcard from J[ames] Everett to William O'Brien thanking him for the beautiful present and souvenir and informing him he tried to contact him and Miss O'Brien to see if they would like to travel with him to Newrath, circa 1923.
Postcard from J[ames] Everett to William O'Brien sending his condolences for Miss O'Brien's ill health and choosing a day to visit, circa 1923.
Circular manifesto of the Irish Textile Workers' Union entitled 'To the Linen Slaves of Belfast' informing textile workers in Belfast of their rights in the workplace and the appropriate minimum wage per hour they should be receiving, circa 1913.
Letter from Roderi[ick?] Connolly to William O'Brien regarding him searching for a job or an appretenticeship in the dockyard and providing him with suggestions of ways he may be able to help him, undated.
Letter from Charles Frank Ridgway to William O'Brien regarding the co-operation between Irish and English dockers in Ireland and organising a possible meeting between the National Union of Dock Labourers and the I.T.& G.W.U. in order to make a deal in regards to dockers in Dundalk and Newry, undated.
Letter from William Field to William O'Brien regarding taking a trip to London and also referring to an enclosed copy, undated.
Letter from A. Lynn to William O'Brien informing him he has some very important news concerning his opponents, the Larkins, and wishes to meet him at his home rather than the offices, undated.
Note stating "M. of D. 17th stated no reason to fear any danger of execution in the case.", undated.
Letter from Rev. Green O.F.S. to William O'Brien introducing him to Mr. G. W. Bartram of the Labour Party and requesting if he could put him in contact with a Labour member to discuss Labour matters in Ireland, undated.
Note written by unknown author to "Oliver" stating "where is the good watch? Judge O'Byrne got the case and he gave me the works.", undated.
Letter from [G?] Duffy to William O'Brien informing him he was charmed by the Seanad elections, speaking of his sympathy towards James Moran, mentioning his ill health at present and also advising that they organise a policy for Labour Party Branches in Dublin City or they will all be called the James Connolly Branch of Tommy Lawlor Branch, undated.
Letter from Nora Connolly O'Brien to William O'Brien thanking him for a copy of 'Forward' in which O'Brien's talk on her father, James Connolly, was printed, informing him of the suggestion to publish Connolly's complete collection and that he can consult "Martin Lawrence" to help in the organisation of the records and also mentioning the Manchester Martyrs, undated.
Letter from Mrs. I. Hughes, secretary of the Dublin Gate Theatre, to [William O'Brien] inviting him and friends to insepct the new theatre, informing him of the opening play and also requesting personal details in order to complete the official register and certificate of his shareholding, undated.
Letter from J. P. Bradshaw to [William O'Brien] informing him he has not received a reply to his letters regarding a small field, undated.
Typescript letter from Dublin Bus Co. to William O'Brien discussing the hopeful end to British Trades Unionism in Ireland and switching half of the trams onto the "paralised routes", undated.
Partial letter from Thomas Johnson to William O'Brien regarding informing the authorities of traffic and general hold ups on Monday, appealing to the public for funds for the Strike Committee and paying shopkeepers for the co-operation during the [general strike in Limerick], undated.
Letter from Peadar O'Donnell, I.R.A. Executive, to William O'Brien informing him that P[atrick] O'Brien has been paid off from work and requesting if William O'Brien can adjust matters in this case in order to help his family, 1922 Jul. 23.
Letter from Rev. John Condon to William O'Brien congratulating him on the result of being acquitted from the charges brought up against him, 1924 Feb. 21.
Letter from William O'Brien to Cathal [O' Shannon] requesting he come up to Dublin for a talk soon, at the expense of the Union, as he is anxious to have him back in the Labour movement, 1924 Mar. 07.
Typescript letter from Eamonn Lynch to William O'Brien thanking him for Ryan's book on James Connolly and advising that a cheap edition would make excellent propaganda, 1924 Apr. 03.
Typescript letter from John J. Murphy, of the Town Clerk's Office, Dublin, to William O'Brien informing him the Minister for Local Government has dissolved the Municipal Council of the City of Dublin and has replaced it with three Commissioners to carry out all duties and therefore O'Brien will not be needed for any further Municipal Council or Committee meetings, 1924 May 20.
Typescript letter from Laurence O'Neill, Lord Mayor of Dublin, requesting a meeting of the members of the corporation due to the suspension of the corporation by the Local Government Board, 1924 May 23.
Letter from [D.?] Mooney to William O'Brien thanking him for taking on the case of Mr Quinn and bringing it to such a satisfactory conclusion and also congratulating him on his recent law case, 1924 Jun. 07.
Letter from Joseph J. Hearne of California to William O'Brien thanking him for sending on a copy of his paper 'The Voice of Labour', introducing him to Michael Scanlon who will be visiting Ireland and is involved in the Labour movement in the US and also asking whether the "Irish people really are as democratic" as they are led to believe , 1924 Jun. 15.
Letter from Ronald W. [Mortshad?] to William O'Brien regarding a speech he made during the conference, a speech Rhys Davies made and also providing information on details of the conference, 1924 Jun. 28.
Typescript letter from [Erin?] Dunne, of 'The Irish Stateman', to William O'Brien regarding writing a recommendation along with William Butler Yeats but informing him that Yeats is currently away completing his book and has left no forwarding address, 1924 Aug. 19.
Note written by [Seán O'Farléin?] to [William O'Brien] requesting if he had any good photographs, sketches or cartoons of James Connolly or James Larkin, 1924 Aug. 22.
Typescript letter from J. J. Walshe to William O'Brien informing him of a private conference being held in the Shelbourne Hotel in order to secure the return of Patrick Leonard and Donal O'Connor in the approaching bye-elections, 1925 Jan. 26.
Letter from P.C. [Trimber?] to William O'Brien speaking of his love for his work in a distillery in Dundalk, which O'Brien secured for him, describing the distillery and the duties of the custom officer and thanking him for taking a fatherly interst in him, 1925 Jul. 15.
Letter from Michael Hayes to William O'Brien informing him his copy of O'Reilly's Irish-English dictionary has arrived, 1925 Jul. 30.
Letter from Éinrí O'Frighil [Henry O'Friel], Department of Justice, to William O'Brien introducing him to Michael Harford of 26 Upper Dorset Street and formerly of Howth, 1925 Sep. 08.
Typescript letter from an unidentifiable author to William O'Brien expressing his regret over a misunderstanding in his payment for articles he wrote for 'The Voice of Labour' and informing him he is not in the position to give so much gratuitous service as before, 1926 Jan. 21.
Letter from [D?] Wallace to William O'Brien thanking him for the inquiries he made for him and the papers he sent on and also informing him he would like to meet him when he travels back to Ireland, 1926 Jun. 03.
Letter from Áine Ceannt to William O'Brien drawing his attention to Dr. Con Murphy's application to the post of Manager of the National Health Insurance section of the I.T.& G.W.U., providing information on his previous posts, discussing the reasons his pension was taken from him and mentioning her compensation should be coming through soon, 1926 Jul. 17.
Letter from Gilbert Lynch to William O'Brien thanking him for informing him of his placement of the panel for candidacy into the Union and the financial support he may receive, discussing the various problems raised by a "J. M. Pringle" and requesting O'Brien use his influence to organise an early conference in Galway to gain support and raise money, 1927 Mar. 10.
Typescript letter from Solon DeLeon to William O'Brien introducing him to Mr. Leroy E. Bowman, who is interested in getting in touch with progressive labour and political movements in Ireland, 1927 Mar. 23.
Letter from Áine Ceannt to William O'Brien thanking him for the information on pensions and getting a matter through that he spoke with Mrs. [Kathleen?] Clarke about, 1927 Mar. 30.
Letter from Joseph McGrath to William O'Brien informing of enclosed books and a cheque to the amount og £5 for the election fund, 1927 May. 10.
Letter from [W. J.?] Ryan to William O'Brien regarding having not heard from Cathal [O'Shannon?] and wishing him luck in his election campaign, 1927 May 26.
Letter from Helena Molony to William O'Brien regarding the large presence of military and police at "Madame's" funeral, mentioning the disgust felt by the public at this and requesting he raise the question at Parliament of whose orders led to the police and military being there, and includes O'Brien's reply letter, 1927 Jul. 22-1927 Aug. 10.
Letter from [Fred?] Conroy to William O'Brien informing him of a meeting between P.Hanigan and the "officials" where he was notified that they were going to move at the next Annual Conference that O'Brien should be removed from his position as General Secretary of the Irish Transport and General Workers' Union, 1927 Jul. 22.
Letter from Ernest Milligan to William O'Brien regarding locating the "Erins Hope" papers which he believes were stored with 'Shan Van Vocht' papers which may have been burnt and also enclosing his thoughts on ways to improve partition relations between the North and South of Ireland, 1927 July.
Letters from Helena Molony and Grace Plunkett to William O'Brien regarding Grace Plunkett receiving a pension from the Irish Volunteers Dependents Fund and the increase in said pension, 1924 Jan. 28-1927 Aug. 10.
Letter from Leroy E. Bowman to William O'Brien regarding having met him and Mr. Johnson in Ireland and mentioning he would like a person like him to be in America, 1927 Aug. 18.
Circular of a testimonial appeal for the raising of funds for Eamon O'Dwyer who played a large part in national and political matters including the Irish language revival and the 1916 rebellion, 1927 Dec.
Letter from John [Seán] R. Moylan to William O'Brien requesting any data he may have on the 'munitions of war' fund the North Cork Sinn Féin office set up during the railway strikes in 1920, in particular a subscription for £1000 as Moylan is being accused of mishandling the money, and includes reply letters from O'Brien stating the records were destroyed, 1928 Jun. 04-19.
Copy letter from William O'Brien to Emanuel Shinwell informing him of an enclosed copy of the Irish Independent in which he is portrayed as "a Communist M.P.", 1928 Sep. 21.
Copy reply letter from Emanuel Shinwell to William O'Brien thanking him for the article from the Irish Independent and informing him he will write to them regarding this, 1928 Sep. 25.
Copy letter from William O'Brien to Emanuel Shinwell informing him he has enclosed a note from the Irish Independent in which they included a correction regarding Shinwell and also mentioning "Kirkwood" was also described as a communist in the Irish Independent, 1928 Sep. 27.
Letter from William Patrick Ryan to William O'Brien informing him he wil do everything possible to spread the knowledge of "Mr. Byrne's" book and reply letter from O'Brien stating he is glad he can help, 1928 Sep. 17-26.
Copy letter from John J. Lyng to William O'Brien informing him of his surprise in seeing Thomas O'Brien's death in the 'Weekly Independent', speaking of his full life, his linguistic qualifications and offering his sympathies to the O'Brien family, 1928 Oct. 19.
Postcard from Kägge Thams to William O'Brien informing him of his ill-health, asking his views on Soviet-Russia and discussing quarrels that are happening between different groups of socialists in Germany, 1929 Mar. 15.
Postcard from Kägge Thams to William O'Brien informing him he has moved to Southern Germany, mentioning his "disease of the lungs" is pulmonary consumption and requesting to hear something from Ireland, 1929 Jul. 20.
Typescript letter from P[atrick] Hogan to William O'Brien thanking him for his letter and enclosed extracts from 'The Framework of Home Rule' by Erskine Childers , 1929 Aug. 12.
Typescript letter from B. [Gifford?] to William O'Brien to refer to his attendence at the 14th Session of the International Labour Conference and informing him he is sending on a copy of the report of the Director of the International Labour Office, 1930 May. 28.
Letter from Patrick O'Kelly to William O'Brien informing him of an enclosed piece of paper containing the name "Mary Feeney", who is looking for a job in Vocational Education and enquiring if "Owen Hynes and Michael Somerville" have committed to any candidates, and if not perhaps they would consider supporting Mary Feeney, 1932 May 10.
Letter from Patrick O'Kelly to William O'Brien regarding the position under the Vocational Education [Committee?] for Mary Feeney he enquired about and informing him of the family resources and income, 1932 May 11.
Typescript letter from Bulmer Hobson to William O'Brien informing him of an enclosed memorandum containing proposals he believes, if considered by the Labour Party, will increase the standard of living of "the great mass of the people" and discussing unemployment and poverty in Ireland, 1934 Apr. 10.
Letter from Thomas Johnston to William O'Brien thanking him for the "Bottomley Book" and discussing his work load, 1935 Dec. 12.
Typsecript letter from Oscar Traynor to William O'Brien apologising for having missed him when he visited the Dáil and mentioning he will inform him of further opportunities of posts that arise for "Miss Whelan", 1936 Mar. 16.
Letter from Michael Brady of Michigan, U.S., to William O'Brien informing him of an enclosed item of a "come-all-y'u" song he sent into WWJ radio station in response to a question posed, discussing their introduction by James Connolly in 1914 and speaking of the "James Connolly Club" in Detroit, founded by Sean Murray and chairmanned by Captain Robert Montieth, 1936 Mar. 27.
Christmas card from Peadar Seán Doyle and Mrs Doyle to [William O'Brien] for the 1936 Christmas and 1937 New Year, 1936 [Dec.].
Copy letter from John J. Lyng to William O'Brien discussing the screening of 'Plough and the Star', a play written by Sean O'Casey and adapted into a movie, in Radio City, New York, and speaking of the size of the theatre and the assorted audience that attended, 1937 Mar. 15
Letter from Joseph McGrath to Bill [William O'Brien] informing him he cannot help in relation to "Hugh Ward" and also that when they move to Ballsbridge he will have to make 30-40% of the male clerical and ordinary staff redundant, 1938 Mar. 18.
Letter from Joseph McGrath to William O'Brien informing him he spoke to the chairman about the nominees he sent him who promised he would "do the needful", 1938 Mar. 18.
Letter from Oliver St. John Gogarty to William O'Brien informing him the deal is to be conducted on Friday and also that he voted Labour, 1938 Jun. 22.
Letter from [R. J. Cremins?] to William O'Brien thanking him for his note of congratulations [regarding his new post as] secretary to the Post Office and reflecting on days passed, 1938 Aug.
Letter from Patrick O'Kelly to William O'Brien informing him he would be glad to be associated with Thomas Foran's send off and also stating he has enclosed a cheque for £1, 1938 Dec. 30.
Typescript letter from Joseph H. Fowler to William O'Brien informing him of two enclosed copies of his book 'Chapters in '98 History' and also that he will try to come to Ireland that year, 1939 Mar. 01.
Letter from Eamonn O'Duibir to William O'Brien discussing his worries that the Pensions Board's decisions that will not be decided upon for South Tipperary cases for "some months to come", informing him of his lack of revenue and requesting a loan in order to procure additional cows, 1939 Apr. 19.
Letter from Eamonn O'Duibir to William O'Brien thanking him for the £20 loan, discussing the "international situation" [WWII] and also of Ireland's policy of neutrality, their victory over conscription and the problem of unemployment and poverty in Ireland, 1939 May 06.
Letter from Joseph J. Bouch to William O'Brien informing him he has found a list of pseudonyms used by the Irish political leaders during the period O'Brien is at present interested in and including a list of three pseudonyms, 1939 May 08.
Letter from [Donald Daly?] to William O'Brien thanking him for the information he sent him regarding 'The Keys of the Bastille' and including a copy of the letter O'Brien sent into the 'Observer', 1939 Aug. 09-10.
Typescript letter from Bishop Michael [Brown] to William O'Brien thanking him for a copy of a pamphlet, 1940 Sep. 17
Copy letter from William O'Brien to his aunt "Mrs. Shovellier" advising her and "Uncle Tom" to move back to Ireland due to the terrible conditions they are under in London and also assuring her he can arrange this move for them, 1940 Sep. 27
Letter from William G. Cruice to William O'Brien thanking him for the socialist literature he sent him, discussing the views of rural Irish people in regards to socialism and their unemployment problem, and also speaking of trade unions in England and America in which he was a member, 1940 Oct. 07.
Letter from Daniel Clancy to William O'Brien informing him he has enclosed £5 he borrowed from him and thanking his for this kindness and including reply from O'Brien on verso, 1940 Oct. 16-19.
Typescript letter from F[intan] P[atrick] Walsh, General President of the Federated Seamen's Union of New Zealand, to William O'Brien introducing Mr. C. M. Ongley, a member of the Union and a qualified solicitor, 1941 Jan. 14.
Letter from Mollie Hall to William O'Brien requesting the address of the chariman of the Labour Party as she is coverning the Labour Party conference for the Daily Herald, 1941 Apr. 16.
Letter from Nora Connolly O'Brien to William O'Brien regarding a position he informed her about in the Distributive Workers Union for her husband Seamus and also informing him that Seamus has put in his application for an exit permit to England, 1941 Jul. 22.
Partial letter from [Nora Connolly O'Brien] to [William O'Brien] regarding her mother and O'Brien receiving pensions for their part in the Easter Rising and the stipulations concerened in receiving one, 1941 Sep. 15.
Typsecript letter from John MacDonagh to William O'Brien thanking him for the leaflets and informing him he sent him on the "buttons", 1941 Sep. 22.
Letter from Mollie Hall to William O'Brien informing him she is marrying Joseph MacColum in January but will be keeping her present job [at the Daily Herald] as they cannot afford otherwise and requesting if the Union would continue to give her items of news, 1941 Dec. 19.
Typescript letter from Desmond Ryan to William O'Brien informing him he has enclosed lists of articles included and excluded in the selection of articles for Connolly's writings and also informing him of mistakes within the lists, 1942 Aug. 09.
Letter from M. J. MacManus to William O'Brien informing him he will look into an assumption O'Brien made in regards to "[James Jeffrey] Roche's Introduction to the [John] Boyle O'Reilly book", 1942 Oct. 20.
Letter from M. J. MacManus to William O'Brien informing him "Frank Callaghan" met "Mr Wheelwright" in New York and his doubts that he had a hand in 'The King's [Men?]' and also referring to 'Belmont Castle' written by Wolfe Tone and his two student friends, 1942 Dec. 02.
Letter from P. O'Dochartaigh to William O'Brien regarding the County Tipperary Labour Party candidates selected for the upcoming general election and providing his opinions on them, 1942 Dec. 21.
Telegraph from J. J. O'Leary to William O'Brien offering his "hearty congratulations and best wishes", 1943 Jan. 29.
Letter from "C. Ongley" to William O'Brien thanking him for his kindness, informing him of his plan to enter medical school with the help of his two friends from New Zealand providing him with money and also referring to "Shylock", 1943 May 12.
Letter from James D. Savage to William O'Brien thanking him for the books he sent to him and his mother, discussing his views on "Gearoid D. Cunningam" and informing him of the econimic classes they hold in the camp, 1943 May 15.
Letter from Joseph McGrath to William O'Brien informing him he will phone in order to organise a meeting the following week and also that the mix up the previous week was due a mistake in his office, 1943 May 20.
Letter from James D. Savage to William O'Brien explaining his delay in replying was due to the hunger strike at the camp, discussing how the writings of James Connolly and his reading of the 'Torch' has altered his political ideology and informing him of his lack of work at present during his three month parole, 1943 Aug. 31.
Typescript letter from R.[oderick] J.[ames] Connolly to William O'Brien informing him he will send him on a fresh copy or the original of a letter from James Connolly addressed to Father Hore, administrator at Wexford, as soon as he can lay his hands on them and expressing his happiness at O'Brien publishing his father's letters, 1943 Nov. 13.
Letter from Daniel Breen to [Thomas] Foran discussing his regret at finding out William O'Brien dislikes him and asking Foran to clear up the situation with O'Brien, including cover letter from Thomas Foran to William O'Brien informing him of the enclosed letter, 1944 Jan. 18-21.
Letter from M[aev] [Healy] Sullivan to William O'Brien regarding his corections and opinions on her book [No Man's Man?] and also clearing up any confusion with the contents of the book, 1944 Jan. 18.
Copy letter from Sean O'hOgain to William O'Brien discussing an idea for a play about "Stephens", speaking of the time he met him and his brother, Daniel O'Brien, in 1894 and mentioning O'Brien's career and family bloodline, 1944 Mar. 09
Copy letter from Sean T. O'Kelly to William O'Brien informing him he has passed on his brother's [Daniel/Thomas O'Brien's?] letters to the secretary of the Department of Finance as he requested, discussing the contents of the letter and mentioning they were of very special interest to him, 1944 Mar. 25.
Letter from M. J. MacManus to William O'Brien apologising for holding onto his book for so long, informing him it is ready to be collected and mentioning he found it of very great interest to him, 1944 Jul. 05.
Typescript letter from R. J. Cremins, Secretary to the Department of Posts and Telegraphs, to William O'Brien informing him he is returning Tom's [Thomas O'Brien's?] letters to him, mentioning that he found them extremely interesting, and also reflecting on the poeple they have lost and others that were mentioned in the letters, 1944 Nov. 28.
Letter from P. Scully to John Murray, Secretary of the Irish Transport and General Workers' Union, asking for information on the progress of Irish workers, requesting he send copies of 'The Voice' to him, for which he will cover expenses for, and speaking of his hopes of permanent security for farmers and workers, 1945 Mar. 08
Typescript letter from Elinor O'Brien to "Friend" [William O'Brien] informing him of an enclosed review she believes would be of interest to him in light of recent events in the trade union movement and querying whether he would like to submit an article for the next issue of 'Irish Workers' Weekly' expressing his views on said issue, 1945 Apr. 04.
Letter from Ambrose V. Martin to William O'Brien speaking of his happiness at having met him as it reminded him of "dear old Ireland", speaking of trade business between Ireland, Spain and France and requesting O'Brien use his influence in Ireland to amend his business being tied to Paris, 1945 Nov. 17.
Letter from "[Joe?] Walsh" to William O'Brien informing him of enclosed photographs he is returning to him and wishing him many happy years of retirement, 1946 Feb. 25.
Typescript letter from Diarmuid Lynch to William O'Brien congratulating him on his retirement and his article in the 'Irish Press', referring to their meeting pre-1916 and comments made in the article regarding his inclusion in Easter Week and the alterations he may have to make to his 1938 statement if the comments are true, 1946 Mar. 01.
Letter from William J. Ryan to William O'Brien thanking him for a copy of 'The Life of James Connolly', discussing the sudden death of his brother and his own ill health, 1946 May 20.
Typescript letter from Thomas Power of California, USA, to William O'Brien informing him he has a membership card of James Connolly from the Irish Socialist Republican Party and Michael Davitt's membership card for the Land League and also requesting he inform him of when he visits as he will provide accomodation, 1946 Jun. 14.
Typescript letter from Thomas Power of California, USA, to William O'Brien informing him he cannot travel due to a broken leg, mentioning he has enclosed the two membership cards of James Connolly and Michael Davitt and providing him with his home address and telephone number, 1946 Jul. 08.
Typescript letter from Thomas Power of California, USA, to William O'Brien apologising for having missed him during his visit to the United States and providing information on his family, 1946 Jul. 25.
Letter from William O'Brien in New York to "Cissie" [Mary Francis O'Brien] describing his travel arrangements and difficulties in obtaining a plane back to Ireland, the meetings he has had with various people, including the lawyer who prosecuted Jim Larkin, and also discussing his day with "Tom's widow" [Thomas O'Brien], 1946 Jul. 31.
Letter from Cathal O'Shannon to William O'Brien informing him [Sean] Lemass will call a conference between the [Congress of Irish Unions] and the Irish Trade Union Congress under his chairmanship, as the Industrial Relations Bill will be operative and informing him of when their team will meet, 1946 Aug. 17.
Letter from [C. D. Watters?] to William O'Brien informing him of his visit to 35 Parnell Square and the confusion that ensued, and also describing the picture of O'Brien done in oils where he is locked up behind bars, 1946 Dec. 20.
Typescript letter from "J. J. Walshe" to William O'Brien thanking him for his kind inquiry regarding his physical conditional, 1947 Jan. 16.
Letter from Helena Molony to William O'Brien informing him of an enclosed picture she is sending him of "Rev. W. Donnelly's" arrest and discussing how she believes it safer with him than Donnelly's family as she believes they would exploit the picture in "some inaccurate or untruthful way", 1947 May 15.
Typescript letter from M[ichael] McDunphy to William O'Brien requesting his help in gathering accurate information in regards to the formation of the Citizens Army as there has been conflicting statements thus far, 1947 May. 23.
Typescript letter from J. C. M. Eason to William O'Brien informing him he has enclosed a file referring to a very small incident that he thinks would interest him, 1948 Jan. 21.
Typescript letter from Edward MacLysaght to William O'Brien requesting he thank Mr. O'Kelly on his behalf for the amount of trouble taken looking into his case, 1948 Apr. 20.
Letter from Sean [McCann?] to William O'Brien thanking him for a copy and congratulation him and everyone invloved in 'Devoy's Postbag', 1948 May 22.
Postcard from Nora C.[onnoly O'Brien] to William O'Brien informing him she presented his book to the "man of the house" and would like to know if he would autograph it, 1948 May 29.
Typescript letter from Michael O'Conor to William O'Brien requesting his help in tracing whether the Sydney Arnold he knew when growing up was the same as a Mr. John Arnall who interrupted a meeting held by the Fiscal Reform League in 1904, 1948 Jun. 08.
Typescript letter from Eamon Martin to William O'Brien informing he has just arrived back for the U.S.A. and very much appreciates him sending on the Devoy book, 1948 Ju. 25.
Letter from Theodore William Moody to William O'Brien confirming a meeting with him and informing a porter a the gate will lead him to his office , 1948 Jun. 30.
Typescript letter from Charles T. Rice to Wlliam O'Brien thanking him for his copy of 'Devoy's Post Bag' and congratulating him on such a wonderful job done, 1948 Jul. 13.
Typescript letter from Colm Ó Lochlainn to William O'Brien containing a paragraph from a letter received from "E. Byrne Hackett of The Brick Row Book Shop, fifty-five fifth avenue, New York, which includes praise for the 'Irish Book Lover' journal and also 'Devoy's Post Bag', which he mentions will be promoted to forty other librarians of Irish ancestry by himself through a sepcial letter, 1949 Jan. 07.
Typescript letter from Michael McDunphy, secretary to the President of Ireland, on behalf of Seán T. O'Kelly, the President of Ireland, to William O'Brien requesting if O'Brien would have any additional information, including the date, those present and the decisions taken, pertaining to a meeting held by the Gaelic League shortly after the outbreak of World War One, 1949 Mar. 10.
Copy letter of reply from William O'Brien to Michael McDunphy informing him of an article he wrote entitled 'James Connolly and Easter Week' and stating he is enclosing a proof of this, which he believes contains the information the President, Seán T. O'Kelly, is looking for, 1949 Mar. 21.
Typescript letter from Michael McDunphy, secretary to the President of Ireland, on behalf of Seán T. O'Kelly, the President of Ireland, to William O'Brien thanking him for the article entitled 'James Connolly and Easter Week', 1949 Mar. 22.
Letter from "Genevieve and John Hearne" to William O'Brien thanking him and his sister, Mary Francis O'Brien, for their kindness during their stay in Ireland and informing him of the various places they visited, 1949 Sep. 28.
Letter from [D. McAllister?], of the Belfast branch of the I.T.& G.W.U., to William O'Brien informing him of the set-up in which to order books and assuring him that he will get a special early delivery of the catologue to order from, mentioning he enjoyed reading 'Devoy's Post Bag' and looks forward to the second volume and also the upcoming Connolly book, and also discussing the books he orders in for the Belfast free library and branch libraries, 1949 Oct. 20.
Letter from "Bob Quinn" to William O'Brien discussing O'Brien's writings on James Connolly and his activities during Easter Rising week and thanking him for sending him a copy, 1949 Dec. 21.
Letter from George Bernard Shaw to William O'Brien informing him he had no contacts or political relations with Jim Connell, albeit, both Socialists, 1950 Jan. 22.
Postcard from Reginald Reynolds to William O'Brien informing him the delay in his reply was due to his travels in India and also assuring him he would be glad of any other corrections Desomd Ryan comes across in the existing edition of 'Labour, Nationality and Religion', 1950 Mar. 31.
Typescript letter from Richards Walshe, T.D., to William O'Brien providing him with the names and address of "Miss Mary Dunleavy" and recommending her for "any postion of trust", 1950 May 09.
Letter from Hugh Ryan to William O'Brien informing him he has enclosed a number of old bank notes to be repaired, mentioning that he is unsure whether they are of any great value and assuring him he will pay any expenses incurred by O'Brien, 1950 Aug. 20.
Typescript letter from unidentifiable author to William O'Brien informing him of travel arrangement to their home and also walking directions from the train station, 1950 Oct. 09.
Letter from Hugh Ryan to William O'Brien regarding the papers of "J. J. Healy", informing him the National Library of Ireland have expressed interest in them and have offered to take them and also mentioning various books he would like to read, 1950 Oct. 27.
Typescript letter from C. Desmond Greaves to William O'Brien informing him he is preparing an historical work including the early history of the Irish Labour Movement and requesting if he may call on O'Brien's home to view his records from this period, in particular that of the Irish Socialist Republican Party, the Workers' Republic and the Socialist Party of Ireland, 1950 Nov. 29.
Copy letter from Patricia Ruston to William O'Brien informing him of an enclosed copy of "Mr. Hanly's" application for Professorship of Architecture in order for him to gauge his standing and qualifications, 1951 Apr. 04.
Letter from J. T. Gwynn to William O'Brien expressing his regret at having not recognised him and stopping him for a talk when they passed eachother by in Dublin and informing him he has been out of journalism and in school mastering for the past fifteen years, 1951 Apr. 14.
Letter from Nora [Connolly O'Brien] to William O'Brien providing him with the address of "Fiona" in Middlesex and discussing an article in the 'Demorcrat', 1951 Apr. 20.
Letter from [Tom Foran?] to William O'Brien discussing the "present generation of Labour people" and mentioning that he does not believe they would do well if they were faced with what O'Brien and himself were faced with in from 1912 onwards, 1951 May. 10.
Letter from unidentifiable author to "Pat" informing him he is at the Geneva Conference and will be unable to travel to Ireland and also hoping he has informed [William] O'Brien of this, 1951 Jun. 27.
Typescript letter from J. F. Cairns to William O'Brien informing him he is currently over from Australia on a Nuffield Fellowship to study the connections between the labour movements in Australia and in the U.K. and Ireland, requesting his assistance in gathering this information regarding Ireland and enclosing a list of questions, 1952 Jan. 07.
Typescript letter from Seán T. O'Kelly, President of Ireland, to William O'Brien thanking him for his "gracious message of congratulations" on his re-election as President for a second term in office, 1952 Jun. 05.
Letter from Udolphus Wright to William O'Brien informing him he will be in hospital for a week of tests, discussing a twist bit satchel he had made in O'Brien's shop and stating he looks forward to meeting and discussing the old Abbey, with attached newspaper cuttings referring to the death of Udolphus Wright later that month, 1952 Oct. 21-Nov.30.
Typescript letter from Richard Mulcahy to William O'Brien thanking him for a copy of Volume Two of 'Devoy's Post Bag' and mentioning he believes the material in this Volume may be more challenging and stimulating than that of the material in Volume 1, 1953 Feb. 05.
Typescript letter from Seán MacEntee to William O'Brien thanking him for his copy of Volume Two of 'Devoy's Post Bag' and suggesting he write his memoirs in order to contribute to the permanent records of the labour and national movements, 1953 Feb. 06.
Letter from Seán T. Ó Ceallaigh, President of Ireland, to William O'Brien thanking him for his copy of Volume Two of 'Devoy's Post Bag', 1953 Feb. 06.
Letter from Patrick O'Kelly to William O'Brien informing him he is returning his "profile" which is a 95% "certificate of character" and informing him "Paddy Connolly" of the Curragh racecourse will be calling him shortly to enquire about a large table for their boardroom, 1953 Feb. 27.
Letter from Patrick Hedderman, New York, to William O'Brien thanking him for his copy of 'Devoy's Post Bag' and discussing the turn of events in New York subsequent to the November elections and introduction of the new administration, 1953 Mar. 01.
Letter from [Maura Quinn?] to William O'Brien informing him she read of his publication, 'Devoy's Post Bag', and congratulating him on the favourable reviews, 1953 Mar. 02.
Typescript letter fom Desmod Ryan to William O'Brien informing him that he has sent a corrected proof of a leaflet to "Fallon's" and also referring to a matter concerning "Mrs. Clarke", "Madge Daly" and "Miss MacSwiney", 1953 Mar. 11.
Typescript letter from Erskin H. Childers to William O'Brien thanking him for the leaflet he sent him written by his father, Robert Erskine Childers, 1953 Mar. 23.
Letter from Patrick O'Kelly to William O'Brien thanking him for the a copy of Volume Two of 'Devoy's Post Bag', informing him that "Paddy Connolly" thought that O'Brien's table was too big and expensive for the club at the Curragh, and mentioning the gravestone that will be erected over Thomas Foran's new grave, 1953 Mar. 30.
Letter from Joseph J. Hearne, California, to William O'Brien thanking him for a copy of Volume Two of 'Devoy's Post Bag', praising the publication, speaking of his family and the current political situation in the United States and also including a photograph of himself, his mother and "Margaret" , 1953 Jul. 12.
Letter from Helena Molony to William O'Brien providing a suggestion of him writing a book dealing with Trade Unionism in Ireland, 1953 Aug. 10.
Typescript letter from Fintan Murphy to William O'Brien informing him of an enclosed photograph of members of the I.R.B., discussing the various different members asked to identify faces in the photograph, with little success, and requesting O'Brien attempt and identify them also, 1955 Apr. 16.
Letter from James O'Brien to William O'Brien thanking him for allowing him to read "this odyssey" of his dear old friend and discussing a likeness in the description in the work of an area to that of Oxford, 1955 Oct. 06.
Letter from "Kathleen [O'Cahalon?]" to William O'Brien agreeing with him that the youth of today do not care or know anything of the pioneers or of history, informing him she is sending his book over to her niece who is studying Irish modern history in Oxford and discussing her part in the "Republican movement" after her fathers death in 1916, [1955?] Sep. 28.
Letter from Helena Molony to William O'Brien expressing her shame of various events that happened during the "Labour Movement", mentioning falsifications in journalism referring to the Irish Womens Workers Union and "Mayor O'Donohoe" stating the I.R.B. announced another Rising to happen before the War was over, and discussing the topics she would like to cover in a short paper she has been asked to write, 1956 Feb. 07.
Letter from Helena Molony to William O'Brien mentioning an article in the Irish Times referring to Jim Larkin and O'Brien's subsequent response, discussing comments James Larkin's made in America referring to the Rebel Leaders of 1916, and also regarding the references made about Jim Larkin's and Padraic Pearse's "close bond" due to his sons attending St. Enda's School, 1956 Mar. 25.
Letter from Joseph McGrath to William O'Brien regarding a position "young Jim" is presently in with a "fellow" and its likeness to a similar positon his father, James Larkin, was in with P. J. Healy, 1956 Mar. 26.
Letter from Reverend W. P. Allen to William O'Brien thanking him for his copy of Volume Two of 'Devoy's Post Bag', congratulating and praising O'Brien and Desmond Ryan on the publication and requesting their autographs, 1956 Sep. 05.
Typescript letter from C. Desmond Greaves to William O'Brien regarding his research of James Connolly's life and asking whether O'Brien knew of a false name Connolly may have used when enlisted in the Militia, 1956 Nov. 13.
Copy letter from D[esmond] R[yan] to William O'Brien regarding his research involving [Rev. David] Moriarty and his views on the Manchester Martyrs, [Terence] de Vere White and inaccuracies in his writings on modern Irish history and Ryan's uncertainty at the facts in the new edition of 'The Rising', 1958 Jan 28.
Letter from Colm Ó Lochlainn to William O'Brien regarding procuring two men for a job in "sales promotion", acquiring two promises of financial support and describing how is company is "constituted", 1958 Aug. 29.
Typescript letter from Fintan Kennedy to William O'Brien informing him on enclosed list of photographs dating from 1909-1916 intended for use in the Golden Jubilee souvenir publication and requesting O'Brien's help with certain photographs, 1958 Dec. 04.
Letter from John [Mulleny?] to William O'Brien informing him of the death of his father, Jack [Mulleny?], and the cause of his death, 1958 Dec. 22.
Invitation from the Irish Transport and General Workers' Union National Executive Council to William O'Brien requesting his presence at the Golden Jubilee Dinner in the Metropole Ballroom, Monday, January 5th at 8pm, 1959 Jan. 05.
Typescript letter from Colm [Ó Lochlainn] to William O'Brien informing him of an enclosed "first bound copy" of 'Labour in Ireland', informing him of corrections made,mentioning the suggestion he proposed to the Union of issuing an advertisement of the four volumes and sending the volumes out to a select few and also includes a draft reply from O'Brien on verso, 1959 Jan. 16.
Letter from Seán Mac Eoin to William O'Brien thanking him for his letter and newspaper cuttings of 1921, dicussing Seán McGrath's capture and sentence to death during the [War of Independence] and informing him he took steps "which saved McGrath's life", 1959 Oct. 09.
Partial letter from the Central Bank of Ireland to William O'Brien informing him he spoke with "P.O'C." [Patrick O'Kelly] and explaing that O'Kelly has work at the moment, mainly social, but would be glad to assist O'Brien with a publication, 1960 Feb. 09.
Letter from Nora Connolly O'Brien informing him she and her husband, Seamus, are unable to visit as he is ill and in the Mater Hospital receiving his second blood transfusion, 1960 Feb. 17.
Letter from G.[erald] Bolard to William O'Brien thanking him for a copy of the Golden Jubillee Book of the Irish Transport and General Workers' Union and describing a photograph in the book that was of particular interest to him, 1960 Mar. 08.
Letter from Eamonn O'Carroll to William O'Brien thanking him for the historic document he sent him and informing him it will be a treasured book on his shelf, 1960 Mar. 12
